webTitle: Should email at work be curbed or nurtured?

fields.headline: Caught up in the communication loop
fields.standfirst:
Should email at work be curbed or nurtured?
Net news
fields.trailText: A man walks into a bar... Why blondes are stupid... What a woman really means when she says... Has anybody seen my pen? No, I haven't gone all Virginia Woolf on you. This isn't my stream of consciousness, it's what you're likely to find in your email in-tray when you return to work after a two-week holiday.
fields.body:
A man walks into a bar... Why blondes are stupid... What a woman really means when she says... Has anybody seen my pen? No, I haven't gone all Virginia Woolf on you. This isn't my stream of consciousness, it's what you're likely to find in your email in-tray when you return to work after a two-week holiday.

And your heart sinks as you scroll down 328 unread messages. Two hours later you're still working your way through them: inane jokes, inane responses to inane jokes, inane responses to the responses.

Occasionally, you'll come across something of import: a date for a meeting, a message from a client, a reminder that you've got an appraisal next week.

By the time you've stored and deleted where appropriate, it's lunchtime. Start work and every thought will be interrupted by that familiar ping, as another email drops into your in-tray.

Steven Roberts, a freelance copywriter, is concerned by the impact email has had on office communication. "Recently," he recalls, "I was working in the offices of a large television company. Nobody spoke to each other - virtually all information was communicated by email. Several times, I announced to my boss that I'd finished a job, only to be told to repeat this information by email and then to await my next instructions by email too. And my boss was sitting right next to me!"

I'm old enough (just) to remember the days before email became a ubiquitous feature in the workplace. The days when people spoke to each other, arranged meetings using diaries and only asked the appropriate person if they had a query, not the entire company.

I'm not a Luddite. I can navigate my way round the web, possess a fax and a mobile phone and, as I write this, digital television is being installed in my living room. But I can't be the only person who feels that email is taking over the office, at the cost of conversation and efficiency.

According to the experts, I'm being alarmist. Psychologist Guy Fielding, a communications specialist at Oxford University, does not agree that email is replacing other forms of office communication. "Most people mistakenly believe in the substitution model for how communication channels work," he says. "We think that when a new form of communication comes along it eliminates the others - the telephone, for example, stops people travelling to see each other or writing letters.

"There's a lot of evidence that this isn't the case. In fact, people who use the telephone the most also travel the most - and every year the number of letters sent increases by 5% to 10%."

Guy believes all channels of communication work as a network, feeding each other. For example, the person you're most likely to telephone is someone you already know face to face. And phonecalls are often made to set up face-to-face meetings.

"When you introduce a new communications medium like email, it has more of an impact on how the other channels are used, not on whether they're used," he states. "People shift some of their activity out of the old channels but continue to use them, but only for the purpose best suited to them."

The problem is that this process can take time. When a new medium is first introduced, people get a little over-excited about its potential, which leads to overuse - hence the flurry of email jokes, chain letters and inane messages wending their way around your office.

Blame it on the innovators of the system, says Guy. "Naturally, they claim it's the system to replace all other systems, but that's not true. In the first flush of enthusiasm people try to do everything using the new medium.

"After a while they learn it doesn't work. When they return to the old systems, their use is refined because they've added another channel of communication. Email is not destructive of other forms of communication. In fact, it probably has the opposite effect."

Adam Joinson, a psychologist at the Open University, says that far from inhibiting or disrupting office communication, email has many benefits. "It's a great tool for brainstorming, decision-making and getting diverse groups in organisations - such as marketing and accounts - to talk to each other. If someone puts you on the spot by asking a question, you may answer rashly.

But using email gives you the time to craft a sensible, articulate response. It's also a great aid to memory: rather than reminding people one by one of a meeting organised weeks ago, you can send a single email."

Adam believes that we tend to over-emphasise how great face-to-face communication is. "When you listen to people talking face-to-face, most of it is not as coherent as you'd expect. In speech, a lot is implied. But in writing you have to focus on your message and spell it out."

Adam has just completed a study comparing levels of self-disclosure in email and face-to-face communication. In the first part of the study, people using a computer chat programme were compared with a group talking face to face. Observers rated how many times they self-disclosed in the course of the conversation. The result? The people using email disclosed four times as much as those conversing face-to-face.

The second part of the study compared email users with those using email and a video-conferencing camera. Again, those who couldn't see each other disclosed more. "Being able to see each other actually reduces the amount of social communication," says Adam. "When they can't see each other, people are more focused and less concerned about being judged. We spend a lot of time focusing on controlling our non-verbal communication - maintaining eye contact, the way we sit, the tone of our voice etc. When using email we can concentrate on the message, not the way we present it."

Email is a great tool for breaking down boundaries. Disability, accent, ethnic origin, dress sense and attractiveness become irrelevant. Instead - and this is the downside - we are judged on the speed of our response and our way with words.

Adam says workers need to be trained in email use. "Research has shown that people who have problems with the amount of emails coming in don't know how to organise them into folders. People aren't properly trained in who to send messages to, or basic email etiquette - like not sending jokes or requests to everyone. Bosses should teach their staff to only check their emails a certain number of times per day so they're not constantly being interrupted."

Many workplaces are cracking down on email use, by forbidding chain emails and personal messages. Adam says that it's important to maintain a balance, so that the social benefits of email aren't lost. "If email use is too tightly controlled, it will stop brainstorming and the forming of communities."

fields.headline: Principle of Denmark
fields.trailText: Perhaps the time has come to revive the idea of the euro as a parallel currency (Denmark says no to the euro, September 29). Neighbouring European countries have long used a form of this arrangement on their borders.
fields.body:
Perhaps the time has come to revive the idea of the euro as a parallel currency (Denmark says no to the euro, September 29). Neighbouring European countries have long used a form of this arrangement on their borders.

To make such a scheme Europe-wide, with the euro alongside the old-fashioned currencies, would have many of the advantages and few of the disadvantages of the single currency. Fears of loss of national identity and of fiscal control would disappear and convenience would be retained. Such a system has worked before: contracts, deals and bank accounts operated readily in the old ecu.
Richard Parish
Manchester

The real debate over the euro is between those who support it because we naively believe it to be a convenient means of exchanging goods and services within the EU and those who oppose it because they don't want the foreign exchange speculators' domination of the global market to be undermined.

As for sovereignty, this has to be economic as well as political or it is meaningless. Most currencies are controlled by people who are unelected, unaccountable and have no political authority.
Abingdon, Oxon
gerald.samson@ntlworld.com

You report that Danish voters said "a resounding no" in the referendum. Come on. Does a slim 53% majority really resound?
Andrew Collins
London acol@dial.pipex.com

Romano Prodi says that "The EU is obviously not happy about this result". Isn't Denmark in the EU? Isn't this top-down attitude what the Danes are protesting about?
Jim Heckle
Järfälla,
Sweden
bedlam@algonet.se

webTitle: Leader: We need envelopes whiter than white

fields.headline: Browned off
fields.standfirst: We need envelopes whiter than white
fields.trailText: Dentists in Scotland have been advised to try using white envelopes, rather than brown, when reminding patients of appointments. Like doctors, dentists waste an enormous amount of time through patients failing to turn up for booked appointments. But a recent study of 5,000 patients at one practice found a large reduction in missed appointments when reminders were sent out in white envelopes, rather than brown. The researchers believe brown envelopes are more likely to get binned on the basis that they are more likely to contain bills.
fields.body:
Dentists in Scotland have been advised to try using white envelopes, rather than brown, when reminding patients of appointments. Like doctors, dentists waste an enormous amount of time through patients failing to turn up for booked appointments. But a recent study of 5,000 patients at one practice found a large reduction in missed appointments when reminders were sent out in white envelopes, rather than brown. The researchers believe brown envelopes are more likely to get binned on the basis that they are more likely to contain bills.

There are several things wrong with this theory. First, most bills no longer come in brown envelopes, perhaps because the marketing departments of utility and credit card companies have already discovered a similar syndrome. These days most gas, electricity and water companies send out their bills in white envelopes. Moreover, even though the envelopes are white, there's little attempt to camouflage what is inside. Thames Water, for example, makes it perfectly clear that there is a bill in the envelopes, with a large blue £ sign accompanied by the more reassuring slogan: "Good news: prices now lower". South West Electricity Board emblazon their bills with a large red SWEB logo on the front. Few people can be in doubt about the bill inside BT's white envelopes.

Brown envelopes are in any case being rebranded. They are now regarded as conveyors of bribes, rather than notices of debt demanding immediate payment. Ask Neil Hamilton. He may still be denying he ever received such envelopes - in fact Al Fayed's personal assistant explained that the £50 notes were placed inside a white envelope inside a brown one - but he graciously accepted a brown one from the Have I Got News For You TV team. Once used by porn peddlers, the brown envelope's main use in debt collection is tax. Dentists should try something simpler: a postcard. It leaves no doubt about its contents.

webTitle: MI6 link to sunken trawler revealed

fields.headline: MI6 link to sunken trawler revealed
fields.trailText: The government has revealed that the retired navy commander who recruited Hull seamen as amateur spies in the cold war years, up to the mysterious sinking of the fishing trawler Gaul in 1974, was a member of the secret intelligence service MI6.
fields.body:
The government has revealed that the retired navy commander who recruited Hull seamen as amateur spies in the cold war years, up to the mysterious sinking of the fishing trawler Gaul in 1974, was a member of the secret intelligence service MI6.

The admission, made in a two-page affidavit from the Ministry of Defence to the high court, has angered the families of the 36 Gaul crew who lost their lives.

They have always suspected that the trawler, which went down in the Barents sea off the coast of Norway, was scuttled by the Russians while on an espionage mission for the Royal Navy. But their effort to get at the facts has been a long and frustrating journey.

"For 26 years we have had lots of lies and deceit and this shows yet another one," said Roy Clark, a member of the Gaul Family Association who lost his son Paul. Mike Sturgeon, whose father Maurice was the crew's mate, said he now hoped that MI6 would open its files on the intelligence operation. "I just want the truth," he said.

MI6's supervision of the spying operation may explain why it was not until three years ago that the Ministry of Defence made the limited admission that Hull boats had been used for surveillance of Russian ships and submarines during the 1960s and early 1970s.

The fate of the Gaul has been one of the enduring mysteries of the cold war and it is still under formal investigation by the former wreck commissioner, high court judge Sir David Steel.

His inquiry is not expected to begin until next year after the wreck is officially reinspected. It was set up last year after a report by the maritime accident investigation branch concluded that the vessel had been swamped by heavy seas entering unsecured deck hatches. But an examination of the wreck by remote cameras failed to find any human remains or personal effects.

To assist Sir David's inquiry, the MoD asked Commander Timothy Clark, a member of the defence intelligence staff, to review ministry records. In his affidavit he says: "I have seen in the MoD records reference to a Cdr Brookes as an intelligence liaison officer in Hull with the crews of fishing trawlers. He retired from the Royal Navy in 1960 and I understand that from then until his death in January 1971 he was a member of the secret intelligence services."

Until now everyone concerned about the case has assumed that Brookes was merely a retired officer who provided the skippers with specialised cameras and recording equipment to gather intelligence for the Royal Navy.

Cdr Clark's affidavit reiterates government information finally released in 1998 that up to 40 trawlers, occasionally carrying surveillance navy personnel, were used for intelligence gathering during the period.

In a carefully worded conclusion he said: "I can confirm from MoD records I have examined, that no record is held which indicates that any member of the crew of the MV Gaul was, or had been, engaged in intelligence activities for the Royal Navy."

But since "no records of trawler personnel involved in this activity exist in MoD files", Cdr Clark adds: "It cannot be stated with absolute certainty that none of the crew... had been briefed on intelligence collection, or issued with photographic or radio equipment, during the 12 months before the loss."

Former Hull seamen have recently testified that both Maurice Sturgeon and the skipper, Peter Nellist, had been on surveillance and hardware recovery operations on other vessels in 1968 and 1972.

Cdr Clark leaves open the possibility that MI6's operations were more extensive than anyone involved in the case has realised. "It is apparent that other intelligence organisations were also involved in intelligence gathering in the Barents sea area in the 1960s," he says.

Max Gold, the Hull solicitor who represents the crew's families, said yesterday: "It is vital new information, very peculiar but not surprising. There has been deliberate deception all along." Mr Gold has written to the Russian ambassador asking for Moscow's intelligence records to be opened.

"What the families really want to know is, what happened to their loved ones and where are their remains," he said.

webTitle: Croydon regains touch of airport glamour

fields.headline: Croydon regains touch of airport glamour
fields.trailText: It takes a giant leap of faith to link the words Croydon and glamour, yet 70 years ago film stars, millionaires and half the crowned heads of Europe swept through the world's first purpose-built international airport.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It takes a giant leap of faith to link the words Croydon and glamour, yet 70 years ago film stars, millionaires and half the crowned heads of Europe swept through the world's first purpose-built international airport.

In Croydon's glory days, visitors took tea on the roof of the airport hotel to peer through binoculars at stars including Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks Jr and Mary Pickford; others paid sixpence to stand on top of a water tower, just to watch planes taking off and landing.

Long after warehouses had covered the old runways, the listed terminal building and the control tower survived as a dismal landmark in an industrial estate in the south London suburb, recorded on the national register of important buildings at risk. Now Airport House has been restored as a business complex, and a small visitor centre has been created in the tower, which opens tomorrow.

"It's hard to believe it," concedes Adrienne Bloch, Croydon council's heritage officer, "but this really was one of the most glamorous places in Britain, the gateway to the Empire."

Croydon International opened in 1920 on an old RAF landing strip. KLM, the Dutch national airline, and Imperial, one of the predecessors of British Airways, were in from the start.

Early planes had a pilot in an open cockpit, and a dozen passengers in Lloyd Loom chairs bolted to the floor beside windows - which they could open if it got stuffy.

Within 10 years there were scheduled flights to Europe, Africa, India and Australia, a journey which took almost a fortnight with overnight stops in hotels and dozens of refuelling stops. Huge crowds came to Croydon to greet Charles Lindbergh who flew in from Paris after he had crossed the Atlantic, and the pioneer long distance aviator Amy Johnson.

In the 1930s the airlines were still sending advice to nervous passengers who had never seen a plane before. "It is not necessary to have a wardrobe specially made for flying," they said comfortingly, while warning gentlemen that some hotels en route would allow lounge suits for dinner, but shorts would never be acceptable.

In the second world war Croydon became an RAF base again, and a target for German bombers: one air traffic controller's diary records, in wavering pencil, an injury to his leg in the first daylight raid in 1940. "Felt rather shaky," he writes, before adding that he was allowed go home early, but was shamefully three hours late for work next morning.

After the war Heathrow and Gatwick were on the rise, while Croydon was too small to take the big new planes. The last flight, a Morton Air Services Heron (preserved outside the building like a moth on a pin) left for Rotterdam on September 30 1959.

When news spread of the restoration, hoarded souvenirs came pouring in: crates of photographs, tickets, uniforms, charts, menus and bone china crockery for the four-course champagne dinners served on night flights to Paris.

"We could have filled the space three times over," Ms Bloch said. "A lot of people have wonderful memories of this place."

Croydon airport opens tomorrow, and the first Sunday of each month, 11am-4 pm; admission free; information from 020-8253 1009

Huge crowds came to Croydon to greet Charles Lindbergh who flew in from Paris after he had crossed the Atlantic, and the pioneer long distance aviator Amy Johnson. In the 1930s the airlines were still sending advice to nervous passengers who had never seen a plane before. "It is not necessary to have a wardrobe specially made for flying," they said comfortingly, while warning gentlemen that some hotels en route would allow lounge suits for dinner, but shorts would never be acceptable. In the second world war Croydon became an RAF base again, and a target for German bombers: one air traffic controller's diary records, in wavering pencil, an injury to his leg in the first daylight raid in 1940. "Felt rather shaky," he writes, before adding that he was allowed go home early, but was shamefully three hours late for work next morning. After the war Heathrow and Gatwick were on the rise, while Croydon was too small to take the big new planes. The last flight, a Morton Air Services Heron (preserved outside the building like a moth on a pin) left for Rotterdam on September 30 1959. When news spread of the restoration, hoarded souvenirs came pouring in: crates of photographs, tickets, uniforms, charts, menus and bone china crockery for the four-course champagne dinners served on night flights to Paris. "We could have filled the space three times over," Ms Bloch said. "A lot of people have wonderful memories of this place." webTitle: McAvennie cleared of drug deal conspiracy

fields.headline: McAvennie cleared of drug deal conspiracy
fields.trailText: The former Scottish international footballer Frank McAvennie was cleared yesterday of conspiring to deal in drugs worth £110,000.
fields.body:
The former Scottish international footballer Frank McAvennie was cleared yesterday of conspiring to deal in drugs worth £110,000.

Newcastle crown court had heard that in March McAvennie, 40, was seen by undercover national crime squad detectives in a car with a friend and an acquaintance travelling to a house in Newcastle upon Tyne, where the friend picked up the drugs.

The acquaintance then took a train to Glasgow and was arrested carrying 5,000 ecstasy tablets and 5kg (11lb) of amphetamine paste, the court was told.

McAvennie, of Gateshead, had pleaded not guilty to conspiring to supply amphetamines and to conspiring to supply ecstasy. He admitted he was in the car but said he knew nothing of the drug deal.

At a previous hearing, he pleaded guilty to possessing a small amount of cocaine, and Judge David Hodson adjourned sentence for reports until October 20.

Outside court, McAvennie, 40, with his girlfriend, Karen Lamberti, thanked the justice system for the verdicts, saying he had been on trial for "something I knew nothing about".

His co-defendant, Arthur Burke, 46, of West Denton, Newcastle, was found not guilty of the same two charges.

fields.headline: To the rescue
fields.standfirst: Are Scottish highland cattle the new sheep?
fields.trailText: Scottish highland cattle are to come to the rescue of one of England's most fragile landscapes in a £1m alliance of farming and conservation groups.
fields.body:
Scottish highland cattle are to come to the rescue of one of England's most fragile landscapes in a £1m alliance of farming and conservation groups.

Their different grazing patterns will be tested by scientists from English Nature and the National Trust as a way of sustaining plants, insects and birds found only on the limestone plateaux of the Yorkshire Dales national park.

The park has joined local farmers and the conservation groups in the £1m bid, which will also test the hill-grazing of hardy cattle as an alternative for beleaguered sheep farmers.

The long-horned and sturdy Scottish cattle may also deter another threat to the area - the illegal amateur quarriers who steal its curiously shaped stones for garden rockeries.

fields.headline: Heavy trading fuels rumours
fields.trailText: Heavy volume combined with an unusual price movement usually means one of two things - a takeover or a profits warning. On Thursday the shares of tour operator Airtours fell sharply in heavy trading, and first thing yesterday the company duly delivered a profits warning.
fields.body:
Heavy volume combined with an unusual price movement usually means one of two things - a takeover or a profits warning. On Thursday the shares of tour operator Airtours fell sharply in heavy trading, and first thing yesterday the company duly delivered a profits warning.

On that basis the movement of Interactive Investor International - up 8p, or 17.98% to 52.5p, on a volume of 1.3m - yesterday means a takeover approach is on the way. Well, that is the theory, anyway.

Yesterday the market gossips were getting very excited by an odd tale that the online personal finance company and former darling of the dot.com boom had received an approach pitched somewhere in the 70p-80p range.

A spokeswoman for the company, which saw its share price hit 415p in March, said chief executive Tomas Carruthers had no comment on the speculation. The sceptics pointed out Interactive's share price is prone to violent price swings, especially on slow Friday afternoons, and the company had made an impressive presentation to the salesforce of investment bank CSFB earlier in the week.

Since warning on revenue growth during June this year, the company has appeared to be in play. Although there have been constant rumours that Interactive has been seeking a buyer, these have always been denied by the group.

This is not surprising, given the fact Interactive is one of the better funded net companies, with around £60m of cash on its balance sheet.

Blue-chip shares, meanwhile, closed a volatile session higher helped by a strong performance from index heavyweight Vodafone, which rose 4.25p to 252.5p.

At the the close the FTSE 100 index was 30.1 points higher at 6,294.2, with BAT putting on the best performance.

The tobacco group climbed 33.75p to 437p on the back of news that a federal judge has dismissed two key parts of the US justice department's lawsuit against the American tobacco industry.

Consumer goods company Unilever advanced 14.5p to 438p as the market warmed to Thursday's EU clearance of its £14.5b acquisition of US food company group BestFoods. Completion of the deal is expected next week.

Railtrack rose 28.5p to £11.09 after UBS Warburg lifted its rating to "strong buy" from "buy".

On the down side, music-publishing group EMI slipped 15p to 540p amid fresh concerns over European regulatory opposition to its proposed merger with Time Warner's music division

Thursday's news that FTSE International, the index provider, will introduce new rules that will led to a radical re-weighting of UK indices hit cable company Telewest, 6p lower at 147.75p, and BSkyB, off 35p at £10.41.

As things stand, Telewest weighing in the FTSE 100 will fall 70% and BSkyB's will decline 60% once the changes are implemented

Retail group Marks & Spencer fell 5p to 203p on talk CSFB has slashed its profits forecasts again.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 gained 4.2 points to 6,676.9, while the Techmark advanced 19.61 points to 3,734.85.

Media group SMG stood out among the mid caps, rising 20.5p to 277p, with dealers attributing the rise to bargain hunting. In the past four trading sessions SMG shares have fallen more than 50p.

Conglomerate Tomkins dipped 7.5p to 165p after it said it had detected signs of a slowdown in its major market.

Steel group Corus dropped 2.25p to 51.25p unsettled by the claim of a Dutch trade union leader who is reported to have said the group could be dead within the year.

Among smaller companies, men's clothing retailer Gieves & Hawkes fell 4.5p to 16.5p in response to news of widening interim operating losses.

United Industries shed some 8p to 17.5p after the group said it would not be able to pay an interim dividend.

fields.headline: Fair swap
fields.trailText: I was interested to read that Canada and Australia deport convicted criminals to their "home" country (Let me disappear, September 28).
fields.body:
I was interested to read that Canada and Australia deport convicted criminals to their "home" country (Let me disappear, September 28).

My flat was broken into by a Chinese national carrying a stun gun. He was apprehended and discovered to be visiting the UK on a tourist visa. Found guilty of burglary and possession of a weapon, he was sentenced to a year in prison, suspended for one year, and immediately released on to the street. I was astonished to learn that the police have no arrangement with the immigration services to organise deportations in such cases.

fields.headline: Vouch for it
fields.trailText: You are right to call for an end to the voucher system for asylum seekers (Leader, September 29). Save the Children knows from its work with vulnerable children seeking asylum that vouchers are both dehumanising and degrading. They shore up racist attitudes and drive asylum seeking families into grinding poverty.
fields.body:
You are right to call for an end to the voucher system for asylum seekers (Leader, September 29). Save the Children knows from its work with vulnerable children seeking asylum that vouchers are both dehumanising and degrading. They shore up racist attitudes and drive asylum seeking families into grinding poverty.

No child should have to make a choice between bus money to get to school and food. But this is exactly the situation asylum seeking children find themselves in.

The review of vouchers is an important opportunity for the voices of the vulnerable to be heard: vouchers are not only dehumanising and degrading but defunct too.
Kate Harper
Save the Children

The real function of vouchers for asylum seekers is to institutionalise the poisonous attitudes behind Jack Straw's berating of bogus asylum seekers. Bill Morris has got this right. The vouchers prepare the ground for racist attacks and are of a piece with Straw's suggestion that the MacPherson inquiry shows that we have the best police in the world.
Prof John Rex
Centre for Research in Ethnic Relations, University of Warwick
johnrex@clara.net

webTitle: Works of art donated in lieu of tax

fields.headline: Works of art donated in lieu of tax
fields.trailText: Britain's galleries, museums and universities are to gain a selection of important works, the arts minister, Alan Howarth, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's galleries, museums and universities are to gain a selection of important works, the arts minister, Alan Howarth, announced yesterday.

The objects have been handed over as part of the acceptance in lieu scheme, where articles of national, historic, artistic and scientific interest can be passed to the government to settle inheritance tax bills.

Among those standing to gain are the University of Cambridge, allocated five sculptures by Barbara Hepworth, and the Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool, which will receive a painting by Jan van Goyen.

Items yet to be allocated by the government include a pair of Chippendale armchairs, a silver Kandler candelabra and three paintings by William Gear.

Lord Evans, chairman of Resource, the council for museums, archives and libraries, said: "The range of objects accepted in lieu of tax demonstrates the breadth of this well-respected scheme and the important role it fulfils in enabling collections across the country to secure important acquisitions."

fields.headline: Independent Energy sued in US
fields.trailText: US investors are suing Independent Energy, the British energy supplier which collapsed this month, and its directors after accusing them of issuing "materially false and misleading" statements.
fields.body:
US investors are suing Independent Energy, the British energy supplier which collapsed this month, and its directors after accusing them of issuing "materially false and misleading" statements.

Lawyers appointed by the plaintiffs warned yesterday that the company faced damages of "millions of dollars" as a result of the legal action.

Joseph McBride, an associate at Rabin and Peckel, the specialist Manhattan-based law firm, said that the action had been brought on behalf of investors who had bought shares in the company between February and September 8 this year, when it collapsed amid billing problems and system failures. Three directors were named in the action: John Sulley, chief executive, Ian Stewart, finance director, and Robert Jones, operations director.

An earlier action brought on behalf of US investors is understood to have targeted the company's underwriters. These were led by Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, the US in vestment bank, and included Prudential Securities.

Independent Energy was unavailable for comment yesterday while DLJ referred any calls to KPMG, the company's official receiver.

The action filed by Rabin & Peckel alleges that: "Independent Energy and certain of its officers and directors violated the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by making a series of materially false and misleading statements concerning the financial condition of the company and the nature and scope of its billing, accounting and collection problems." US investors are furious at being sold shares at £30.95 in a share offering in March, two months before industry regulator Ofgem suspended the company.

The legal actions provide an embarrassing endnote to a company that had been last year's market favourite.One of few companies to take on the entrenched monopolies in the UK energy sector, it soared to a stock market high of £36 in March after attracting 260,000 electricity and 65,000 gas customers.

webTitle: Hyder chief faces flak over Welsh agency post

fields.headline: Hyder chief faces flak over Welsh agency post
fields.trailText: Graham Hawker, the man who oversaw the foreign takeover of multi-utility Hyder, Wales's biggest public limited company, after it ran up £1.9bn in debt, yesterday faced flak after being appointed chief executive of the Welsh Development Agency, so-called powerhouse of the new Welsh economy.
fields.body:
Graham Hawker, the man who oversaw the foreign takeover of multi-utility Hyder, Wales's biggest public limited company, after it ran up £1.9bn in debt, yesterday faced flak after being appointed chief executive of the Welsh Development Agency, so-called powerhouse of the new Welsh economy.

Mr Hawker, a miner's son from the Rhymney valley and former council clerk who rose to become Hyder's chief executive, is taking a huge pay cut to run the WDA.

He will be paid £95,000 a year, with performance bonuses; at Hyder he earned more than £300,000.

Unanimously approved by the WDA board, where he has been deputy chairman, Mr Hawker was forced to defend his corner amid accusations that he drove Hyder into the arms of American group Western Power Distribution after failing to staunch a haemorrhaging in the Welsh group's finances which saw its shares slump from more than £10 to below £2.

WPD won a bidding war for Hyder against Japanese bank Nomura with a controversial last-minute 365p a share offer in a takeover panel auction in August, ending Mr Hawker's more than 20-year career at Welsh Water-Hyder.

Gregarious Mr Hawker, criticised in the City for his poor management, yesterday insisted he felt "no embarrassment" at being chosen as WDA chief executive from among 44 candidates, and denied Hyder's demise was attributable to mismanagement.

fields.headline: At this price?  RM
fields.trailText: RM, the computer software supplier for the education sector, rallied from a 12% slide in its share price in early trading yesterday to close the day 12.5p lower at 890p. The fall had been triggered by a trading statement which warned that profits would be hit by a delay in the award of a contract to supply all 1,227 schools in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
RM, the computer software supplier for the education sector, rallied from a 12% slide in its share price in early trading yesterday to close the day 12.5p lower at 890p. The fall had been triggered by a trading statement which warned that profits would be hit by a delay in the award of a contract to supply all 1,227 schools in Northern Ireland.

RM announced at its interim results that its joint venture with ICl called Trilith had been made sole bidder for the contract worth £300m over ten years. The company has still failed to agree on commercial terms under the government's private finance initiative. Pending the decision, RM chief executive Richard Girling said the group would be forced to make a provision of £2.1m against costs incurred in anticipation of the contract being won.

For the full year, it will make a £5.5m provision including the cost of employing 50 extra IT staff who have been running demonstrations for Northern Ireland's department of education.

Mr Girling said: "It is disappointing to report that, after investing so much time and effort, we have been unable to reach agreement within the time frame anticipated. We have, however, made significant progress in the second half and remain hopeful of reaching agreement on satisfactory commercial terms." Brokers downgraded their forecasts for this year accordingly but the profit warning failed to make a longer term impact.

House broker UBS Warburg is holding its pre-exceptional profits forecast at £14.9m for 1999/2000 while the following year forecast is for £17.3m. Despite the increased provisioning, Warburg has set a £10 target on the shares.

Yesterday's statement should be a blip. Earlier this week, the government announced an extension of the national grid for learning programme which has increased funding for IT in the education sector from £450m between 2000/2002 to £710m over 2003/2004.

fields.headline: All change at bus firm
fields.trailText: The new millennium has not been kind to investors in Mayflower Corporation, the quoted engineering group that designs and makes car and bus bodies, and boasts former prime minister John Major an non-executive director.
fields.body:
The new millennium has not been kind to investors in Mayflower Corporation, the quoted engineering group that designs and makes car and bus bodies, and boasts former prime minister John Major an non-executive director.

Since news of Mr Major's appointment in December last year Mayflower shares have fallen from 211p to yesterday's closing price 84.5p.

However help could now be at hand for beleaguered shareholders in the shape of John Harvey, a secretive Barbados-based investor. Mr Harvey has appeared on the share register with a 4.08% holding.

Not much is known about Mr Harvey, other than the fact that he made a sizeable fortune in the automotive industry.

City insiders insist he is a man to watch. According to market sources Mr Harvey has a history of investing in undervalued situations and could if necessary reverse a company's fortunes.

fields.headline: Union seeks tax on banks
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The head of finance union Unifi is calling on the government to use a windfall tax as a weapon against the banks if they continue to refuse to support the post office-based universal bank, according to proposals seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The head of finance union Unifi is calling on the government to use a windfall tax as a weapon against the banks if they continue to refuse to support the post office-based universal bank, according to proposals seen by the Guardian.

Ed Sweeney, the general secretary of Unifi, is advocating that "compulsion rather voluntary" measures should be adopted in order to tackle financial exclusion.

In his proposal, which is not the official stance of the union, Mr Sweeney says: "If we are serious about tackling financial exclusion we need to think of a different strategy - one that relies on compulsion rather than being voluntary. So why not a one-off windfall tax on all banks, with the proceeds ring-fenced into paying for the universal bank?".

One of the aims of the controversial universal bank is to give accounts to the 4m people who do not have them. The move is particularly crucial for the government as it wants to automate social security payments by paying them directly into accounts.

As well as attempting to tackle financial exclusion, the universal bank is at the heart of government strategy to retain the post office network.

Mr Sweeney stressed that the tax should be levied on all the banking players, not just the high street names such as Barclays and Lloyds TSB. The new internet and telephone banks should also be affected by the measure, he said.

"Although the branch-based banks say they do have a social conscience, the internet and phone banks, busy targeting the top end of the market, do not care about poor people and so are not interested in putting anything towards the universal bank at all," Mr Sweeney said.

fields.headline: Airbus secures £5.8bn A3XX deal
fields.trailText: A £5.8bn order yesterday for the A3XX, the world's largest aircraft, by Singapore Airlines has made it virtually certain that the project to manufacture the craft will go ahead by the end of the year.
fields.body:
A £5.8bn order yesterday for the A3XX, the world's largest aircraft, by Singapore Airlines has made it virtually certain that the project to manufacture the craft will go ahead by the end of the year.

The company announced that it would buy 10 aircraft, each capable of carrying up to 900 people, with options on another 15 from Airbus, the European consortium in which Britain has a share.

This takes the number of firm orders up to 32. It is the biggest single order for the plane, although Emirates, the Middle East airline, was the first to reveal that it would be buying the plane at the Farnborough air show in July.

Airbus says that it needs between 40 and 50 orders before it can start to build the aircraft commercially.

Before yesterday's announcement by Singapore, it had received 22 firm orders, including those from Air France and Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic.

Cheong Choong Kong, Singapore's chief executive, said: "Our decision to be a pioneer is further evidence of our determination to stay ahead."

A fierce battle is likely to develop between Emirates and Singapore on who will be the first to fly the aircraft. This depends on how quickly Airbus is able to build the plane at its factory at Toulouse, in France. Both airlines have made it clear that they want to start flying into Heathrow as early as 2005. But Noel Forgeard, Airbus's chief executive, suggested that the A3XX would be flying in Singapore colours before Emirates.

He said he was confident of obtaining the remaining 18 orders necessary to top 50 in the next few months. Qantas, the Australian carrier, is likely to join the list.

Mr Kong said that the company was already in touch with the Heathrow authorities to make sure that the A3XX met the airport's noise requirements in six years.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Interbrew aims for clearance
fields.body:
Interbrew aims for clearance

Belgium's Interbrew is confident its deal to buy the beer business of Bass will be cleared by the UK authorities, and says that its own stock market flotation is still on track for later this year.

Privately owned Interbrew, which brews Stella Artois and Labatt beers, bought Bass Brewing for £2.3bn in June, one month after purchasing Whitbread's beer business for £40m, pushing it to number two spot in the world beer league.

The deal for Bass was referred to Britain's competition commission with a final outcome expected on the deal from the government by January 6 next year.

MultiMedia in merger deal

The MultiMedia Corporation has said it will merge with technology investment house Illuminator in order to start a £50m-£100m fund to invest in troubled dot.com and technology companies.

The resources for the new fund, to be called Techrescue, will be raised by Brian Myerson and Julian Treger, who together run Active Value Advisors and started Illuminator in 1999.

The pair, who are committed personally to raising the money from individual and institutional investors, will become joint executive chairmen of the new company.

Diageo director scores big

One of Diageo's top directors, Jack Keenan, earned a £1m-plus bonus last year - which boosted his salary to more than £2m, according to the group's annual report.

Mr Keenan, 62, now deputy chief executive of Diageo's main operating unit Guinness UDV, was rewarded with the bonus despite a dismal reward for shareholders who have seen Diageo shares little moved since the group's formation in December 1997.

Baird confirms buyout talks

Textiles group William Baird yesterday confirmed it was still in talks which could lead to a management buyout.

The company, now suing high street retailer Marks & Spencer for axing a long-term contract, plans to make an announcement within weeks.

It is thought David Suddens, Baird chief executive and leading the talks, is hoping to make a cash offer to shareholders. The comments came as Baird announced doubled pre-tax profits to £4.5m for the six months to June.

webTitle: Croatia's president gives seven generals their marching orders

fields.headline: Croatia's president gives seven generals their marching orders
fields.trailText: The president of Croatia, Stipe Mesic, yesterday sacked seven army generals for complaining that the government was insulting the memory of the country's war for independence by prosecuting alleged war criminals for atrocities committed against Serbs.
fields.body:
The president of Croatia, Stipe Mesic, yesterday sacked seven army generals for complaining that the government was insulting the memory of the country's war for independence by prosecuting alleged war criminals for atrocities committed against Serbs.

Mr Mesic's tough move was a sign of how far things have moved since the death of President Franjo Tudjman and the election of a liberal government which wants to restore links with the rest of Europe.

As well as being a rare case of a country willing to try its former military elite - not just for corruption but for war crimes - Croatia's trials could be a precursor to similar action in Serbia, if the opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, succeeds in removing Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, from power.

Although he has criticised the international criminal tribunal in the Hague for being an instrument of US interests, Mr Kostunica has left open the option of starting war crimes trials or a state-sponsored "truth commission" in Serbia.

He says Serbia must confront its role in the last decade of Yugoslavia's civil wars.

The seven Croatian generals who were sacked yesterday - Ante Gotovina, Kresimir Cosic, Damir Krsticevic, Ivan Kapular, Milenko Filipovic, Davor Domazet-Lose and Mirko Norac - were among 12 active and retired generals who made their allegations in an open letter published on Thursday. They were strong supporters of Tudjman's nationalist government.

In the letter they noted "with bitterness" that the 1991 war against Yugoslavia has been presented "as a crime and something filthy, while in fact it was the foundation of Croatia's freedom, independence and sovereignty".

They accused Mr Mesic and the government of "waging a campaign to smear the independence struggle through recent spectacular arrests".

The generals were referring to the new government's decision to hold trials as well as to cooperate with the war-crimes tribunal in the Hague, even if the perpetrators were Croats.

Investigators from the tribunal began looking for the graves of an estimated 120 Serbs in Gospic, central Croatia, earlier this year.

In forcing them into retirement, Mr Mesic cited a constitutional ban against senior military officials publicly airing political views. "My message to those who think they can bring down the government with pamphlets is that they are playing the wrong hand," he said, adding that the army must be "depoliticised".

"Whoever wants to be involved in politics has the right to do so; I won't suggest which party they should join. But while they are in the army they will not be publishing pamphlets," Mr Mesic said.

The generals' protest follows the arrest earlier this month of four Croats suspected of killing Serb civilians in Gospic in 1991. Police also arrested several soldiers accused of slaughtering civilians in neighbouring Bosnia.

Angry war veterans have been demonstrating against the arrests in Gospic on a daily basis for several weeks.

In September, Milan Levar, a key witness, was killed by a bomb outside his home in Gospic. He had helped to defend the town in 1991 when local Serbs rebelled against Croatia's declaration of independence. But he was so shocked by his own side's actions that he decided to give evidence to the war-crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Reporters in Gospic were threatened by the crowd during an arrest there two weeks ago. A radio reporter in Zagreb was also accosted by a man who put a pistol into his mouth, threatening to kill him.

Ironically, despite Croatia's willingness to work with the Hague tribunal as well as to conduct its own trials, there is some resentment in Zagreb about the west's rush to lift sanctions on Yugoslavia and forget the war-crimes issue once Mr Milosevic leaves power. "I don't think sanctions should be lifted until Yugoslavia does what we did: adopt a law on cooperation with the Hague tribunal and extradite its war-crimes suspects," Mr Mesic said this week.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Floods swamp Bangladesh
fields.body:
Floods swamp Bangladesh

More than 1m people have been left homeless by the worst floods in south-western Bangladesh in 60 years. The poor have been worst hit as the floods swept away their mud and thatch homes.

Officials said that eight people had been killed by the floodwaters which poured over the border from the Indian state of West Bengal. The rescue operation is being hampered by a lack of boats and because most road links have been cut. Observers said the death toll was likely to be much higher.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Police swoop on porn surfers

After a major sting against child pornography on the internet, hundreds of people are under investigation across Germany for visiting a website showing illegal pictures of minors, police said yesterday.

Police raided the homes of 13 suspects in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt, seizing computers, floppy disks, compact discs, and magazines in search of downloaded images. In the western state of North-Rhine Westphalia alone, police said they were investigating 258 people.
AP, Frankfurt

Elephant sparks jumbo problem

An elephant broke through a wall and strolled around Gauhati airport in the Indian state of Assam yesterday, forcing an airliner to circle the city twice while firecrackers and flares were used to drive the animal away.

Expanding human populations are encroaching on the elephant habitat and more of the animals, protected under Indian law, are appearing in cities and villages. Fifty people have been killed by elephants this year in Assam.
AP, Gauhati

webTitle: Friends defend Greece's most hated man

fields.headline: Friends defend Greece's most hated man
fields.standfirst: Safety checks ordered as unions tell of pressure on captains of substandard ferries
fields.trailText: Random checks of Greece's ageing ferries were ordered yesterday as evidence grew that the crew of the Express Samina, which sank off Paros on Tuesday with the loss of at least 75 lives, was far from alone in flouting safety regulations.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in Paros and Michael Howard in Athens
fields.body:
Random checks of Greece's ageing ferries were ordered yesterday as evidence grew that the crew of the Express Samina, which sank off Paros on Tuesday with the loss of at least 75 lives, was far from alone in flouting safety regulations.

An appeal court prosecutor ordered safety inspections on vessels at major ports after seafarers' unions said the owners were covering up the fact that virtually all ferries were substandard. Captains were pressured to sail close to rocks to save time and dissenters were silenced, it was claimed.

"If you report a problem you're in danger of losing your job," Yannis Manousoyanakis, the head of the Greek seamen's union, said.

Vangelis Kouzilos, president of the masters and mates union, said that captains were forced to race in and out of poorly built harbours.

The safety checks were ordered as most of the survivors of the sinking, including 14 Britons, were taken from Paros to Athens. No Britons were among the dead.

Divers and fishermen yesterday recovered 10 more bodies, but it is feared a handful remain entombed in the ferry, 40 metres (130ft) beneath the waves.

The captain of the Express Samina, Vassilis Yannakis, and three crewmen have been placed under a blanket charge of multiple manslaughter with possible intent. Specific and individual charges are expected to be formally laid at a hearing on the island of Syros tomorrow.

The Guardian learned that Capt Yannakis had been complaining for years that the Express Samina, owned by ferry company Minoan Flying Dolphins, was not seaworthy.

Tessy Econonomopoulo, a journalist with the shipping magazine Efoplisti and a friend of the captain, said engine failure and steering difficulties often forced the 34-year-old boat to limp into port. "He said he had saved that ferry countless times."

She said Capt Yannakis behaved in the same way as his colleagues plying the Aegean.

"If he is a criminal then we are all criminals. He's a quiet man and patient man, perhaps too quiet and patient. He often gets saddled with crew that no other captains want. Perhaps he should be more assertive."

Five years ago all systems failed as the Express Samina entered Karlovassi harbour on Samos. In darkness, Capt Yannakis steered with anchors, and passengers disembarked oblivious to how close they had come to disaster.

Afterwards he told Efoplisti magazine: "What can I say? Did God shine some light on me? In these situations other powers are at work."

Anger at Minoan Flying Dolphins deepened as another of the company's ferries, the Express Artemis, became stranded at the island of Naxos, near Paros, as a result of engine failure late on Thursday. One of its hydrofoils caught fire last month.

The company insisted that inspectors had judged the Express Samina fit to sail and that Tuesday's accident was caused solely by human error.

Speaking outside a court room in Syros, Capt Yannakis, 53, apologised. "This is the only thing I can say. As a captain of Greek shipping, I take full responsibility for the victims and I am very sorry for what happened. That's all."

The ferry sank within minutes of crashing into a well-charted islet with a lighthouse, throwing about 530 passengers into dark, rough waters two miles from Paros.

Witness accounts that the captain was watching a football match were contradicted by excerpts from the accused men's testimony, published in Ta Nea newspaper, which said he was asleep in his cabin. According to the regulations, he should have been on the bridge when the ferry came within seven miles of Paros, but such stipulations were routinely ignored by captains plying familiar waters, Ms Econonomopoulo said.

The captain's deputy, Anastasios Psychoyos, was allegedly flirting with a passenger and rushed to the bridge when the helmsman, Panayotis Kasdaglis, shouted.

Mr Psychoyos told reporters: "The weather pushed us on the rocks. We had maintained a safe distance."

From his cell the captain reportedly told a friend that he wanted to go down with his ship, but instead slid into the water. Two hours later he was hauled aboard a life raft by a passenger who did not recognise him because he was out of uniform.

Several off-duty crewmen in pyjamas were mistaken for passengers as they handed out life-jackets, fuelling claims that they fled the chaos.

Seafarers' union leaders have condemned the government and media for assuming the captain's culpability and turning him into Greece's most hated man.

fields.headline: Vanunu put back in solitary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Mordechai Vanunu, the Israeli nuclear whistle-blower, has been thrown back into solitary confinement and told he will not be released from prison until the end of his 18-year sentence in 2004.
fields.body:
Mordechai Vanunu, the Israeli nuclear whistle-blower, has been thrown back into solitary confinement and told he will not be released from prison until the end of his 18-year sentence in 2004.

The decision was taken after the 44-year-old technician became involved in a row with guards at Ashkelon jail near Tel Aviv after he left the exercise yard to sit in the sun for a brief period, the British Campaign to Free Vanunu said yesterday.

The campaign will hold a vigil today outside the Israeli embassy in London to mark the 14th anniversary of his abduction by the Israeli secret service.

"These violations of human rights will not deter the campaign continuing to fight for Mordechai's freedom," the campaign coordinator, Ernest Rodker, said yesterday.

"They show how brutal the Israeli authorities can be when wishing to crush a courageous prisoner who has been determined not to be silenced."

Vanunu, a former technician at Israel's nuclear reactor at Dimona, in the Negev desert, was lured from London to Rome by a female Mossad agent in 1986 and abducted there after providing information about the plant to the Sunday Times in Britain.

He spent his first 11 years in jail in solitary confinement before being allowed brief exercise periods and periodic visits from his family. His supporters point out that he never approached a foreign power and disclosed information to the Sunday Times long after he left Israel, and only as a result of his conscience.
fields.bodyText: Mordechai Vanunu, the Israeli nuclear whistle-blower, has been thrown back into solitary confinement and told he will not be released from prison until the end of his 18-year sentence in 2004. The decision was taken after the 44-year-old technician became involved in a row with guards at Ashkelon jail near Tel Aviv after he left the exercise yard to sit in the sun for a brief period, the British Campaign to Free Vanunu said yesterday. The campaign will hold a vigil today outside the Israeli embassy in London to mark the 14th anniversary of his abduction by the Israeli secret service. "These violations of human rights will not deter the campaign continuing to fight for Mordechai's freedom," the campaign coordinator, Ernest Rodker, said yesterday. "They show how brutal the Israeli authorities can be when wishing to crush a courageous prisoner who has been determined not to be silenced." Vanunu, a former technician at Israel's nuclear reactor at Dimona, in the Negev desert, was lured from London to Rome by a female Mossad agent in 1986 and abducted there after providing information about the plant to the Sunday Times in Britain. He spent his first 11 years in jail in solitary confinement before being allowed brief exercise periods and periodic visits from his family. His supporters point out that he never approached a foreign power and disclosed information to the Sunday Times long after he left Israel, and only as a result of his conscience.

webTitle: Mandela joins chorus of criticism against Mbeki's stance on Aids

fields.headline: Mandela joins chorus of criticism against Mbeki's stance on Aids
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela has added his voice to the growing band of powerful critics who have chastised the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, for questioning the existence of a direct link between HIV and Aids.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela has added his voice to the growing band of powerful critics who have chastised the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, for questioning the existence of a direct link between HIV and Aids.

In unusually direct criticism of his successor, the former president told a South African newspaper that he shared the "dominant opinion that prevails throughout the world" that HIV causes Aids, and that he would only change his mind if science proved "conclusively that that view is wrong".

Mr Mandela, who this week told the Labour party conference in Brighton that Aids was killing 10 teachers a week in South Africa, went on to say that public figures should not flirt with unscientific theories when so much was at stake.

"I would like to be careful because, for people in our position, when you take a stand, you might find that established principles are undermined, sometimes without scientific backing," he said.

Mr Mandela has previously shied from open criticism of his successor on Aids and other issues, but the former president had said that he believed the disease was the greatest threat facing Africa.

He said the government's focus should be on combating Aids through education and treatment, not on debates about its causes.

The ground for Mr Mandela's condemnation was laid last week by similarly direct attacks on Mr Mbeki's stance on Aids: South Africa's powerful trade union confederation called the link between HIV and the disease "irrefutable", and the Anglican archbishop of Cape Town, Njongonkulu Ndungane, likened the government's refusal to supply drugs to HIV-positive people as "as serious a crime against humanity as apartheid". Some 4.2m citizens out of a population of 43m are HIV positive.

Mr Mbeki does not deny outright there is a link between HIV and Aids, but says it is just one factor among many causes of Aids that include social factors such as poverty.

webTitle: Farmers see profits pruned by religious zeal

fields.headline: Farmers see profits pruned by religious zeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Dripping with sweat in the afternoon sun, farmer Shimon Sebban wills on the workers slashing their way through his vineyard, until the dry earth is hidden beneath mounds of green branches. "I am going to have to stand on their heads to finish on time," he says.
fields.body:
Dripping with sweat in the afternoon sun, farmer Shimon Sebban wills on the workers slashing their way through his vineyard, until the dry earth is hidden beneath mounds of green branches. "I am going to have to stand on their heads to finish on time," he says.

Pruning is a task normally reserved for the lazy days of winter, but this year's growing season is turned topsy-turvy by an inconvenient passage from the Bible. From sunset yesterday, for one full year of the Jewish calendar, Mr Sebban is forbidden to plant, hoe, or prune.

The injunction is irritating even for traditionalists, like Mr Sebban's cousin and fellow farmer, Eli Sella. "This goes against the laws of nature," Mr Sella complains. "We are still picking the red grapes. How can we prune, while we are picking?"

The farmers can - indeed must - because of Leviticus 25: 3-4: "Six years thou shalt sow thy field. But in the seventh year shall be a sabbath of rest unto the land, a sabbath for the lord. Thou shalt neither sow thy field nor prune thy vineyard."

This year, 5761 on the Jewish calendar, happens to be a seventh year, the shmita, or letting go. So even before he saw to his grapes, Mr Sella took care of his artichokes, planting them weeks earlier than usual to escape the ban.

Observing shmita is not usually a problem because Israelis are expert at ruses to reconcile Jewish religious dictats with modern practicalities. Some observances of the fallow year have withered and died - like remission of debt. Others, such as "selling" land to non-Jews, are practised by sleight of hand.

But this is a season of tensions, with orthodox Jews buffeted by the "secular revolution" promised by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, and efforts by the ultra-orthodox to usurp their control of the rabbinate. Meanwhile, Sephardi Jews, or those from Arabic-speaking countries, are chafing at the dominance of the European establishment.

All these rivalries converged when some rabbis set out to prove they were holier than their brothers by striking down the cosy compact of imaginary land sales. They decreed that they would cancel the kosher certificates of supermarkets and grocers stocking local vegetables during the shmita - measures that could send food prices reeling.

Mr Sella and Mr Sebban view the wrangling with growing alarm. For the cousins, the merest suggestion that their grapes and artichokes are non-kosher could spell economic ruin. Supermarket chains would shun them for fear of alienating Jews who keep the dietary laws - perhaps half of all Israelis. Their grapes and artichokes would be welcome in only a few secular strongholds.

Although 80% of the grapes grown at Beit Uziel are sold to Marks & Spencer, Mr Sella is unwilling to risk the stigma.

"I was looking at bankruptcy," says Mr Sella, who is 700,000 shekels (£120,000) in debt. Like all farmers, he has been hit hard by the decline of what was once Israel's primary industry. Agriculture now accounts for only 3% of GNP.

So he and the other 65 families in this farming community in central Israel have consulted their rabbi to devise a solution. Instead of an imaginary land sale, they have sold their entire grape crop in advance to the Israeli rabbinate.

That will assure the farmers of a buyer when the harvest rolls around next March - although the rabbinate did not fix a price and, according to Mr Sella, proved a hard bargainer. "They squeezed every last bit of life out of me before they gave me an advance."

But what is good for grapes is not good for artichokes. For that crop, Mr Sella has obtained the usual kosher certificate for a shmita year, even though it is no longer recognised by some rabbis.

"The ultra-orthodox will not be eating my artichokes," he says. "But I will manage."

fields.headline: Bedlam strikes the holy city
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The most hallowed ground in the holy city - and the volatile core of the Israeli-Arab conflict - was doused in blood yesterday as rioting between Muslim worshippers and Israeli police left four Palestinians dead, and as many as 200 wounded.
fields.body:
The most hallowed ground in the holy city - and the volatile core of the Israeli-Arab conflict - was doused in blood yesterday as rioting between Muslim worshippers and Israeli police left four Palestinians dead, and as many as 200 wounded.

The violence erupted at the close of afternoon prayers when Israeli riot police stormed the Haram al-Sharif, the site of the Dome of the Rock that is the third-holiest shrine in Islam, firing live rounds and rubber bullets at stone-throwing Palestinian youths.

Dozens of police, including the Jerusalem police chief, were hit by stones after the violence was stoked by the arrival of more than 22,000 people for prayer.

With peace negotiations locked for weeks over the fate of the Haram - which Jews claim as the site of their destroyed temple - and Israel mourning a border policeman who was killed by a member of the Palestinian security forces earlier yesterday, the clashes could escalate out of control; violence also broke out in several areas of the West Bank.

It was the second consecutive day of rioting on the Haram, following the provocative visit there on Thursday by the leader of the hardline Likud party, Ariel Sharon, in a blatant display of Israel's iron grip on the heart of Muslim Jerusalem.

By the time the muezzin called the faithful to prayer yesterday, tempers were menacingly high, with Palestinians bridling at the large Israeli presence on their hallowed ground. "It is forbidden for them to come inside with their sticks. This makes our young men explode," said Sami Bibi, who lives in east Jerusalem, occupied illegally by Israel since 1967. "When I was praying they were hanging over my head."

The Israelis say scuffles broke out when Palestinians began raining stones on the heads of Jewish worshippers at the Wailing Wall, below the Haram. They soon turned ugly.

"If you went toward the gate they would shoot at you. People were just trying to get out and they shut the gate," said Israr Hussain, a tourist from Halifax.

"As soon as the prayers finished, they started firing," said Abu Assab Khader, whose right calf was pierced by a rubber-coated bullet. "They shot at us like dogs - no, flies."

There were reports that the Israelis used live ammunition.

"I saw two or three people with their brains outside their head," said a doctor at the nearby Muqassad hospital, who would not give his name. "That was not [caused by] rubber bullets."

The Israeli version of events was different, with a government spokesman, Moshe Fogel, blaming Muslim clerics for setting events in motion with incendiary prayers.

As the day wore on, the rioting spread to other neighbourhoods of Arab east Jerusalem, and outlying villages, where five tourists were hurt when their bus was stoned. Street violence also rocked Palestinian-ruled areas, with clashes reported in the West Bank towns of Bethlehem and Ramallah, and in Gaza. Crowds of Palestinians, some clutching iron bars, took to the roads, setting fire to Israeli cars.

Palestinian radio called the two days of clashes on the Haram the start of "the battle for Jerusalem".

Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, said they were "extremely serious". "I spoke to [Palestinian leader Yasser] Arafat today and I made it clear to him that attacks such as this are totally unacceptable and that we expect the Palestinian authority to do everything in its power, using all the means at its disposal, against perpetrators of terrorist acts," he said.

webTitle: BAT shares leap after US court victory

fields.headline: BAT shares leap after US court victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: BAT celebrated a legal victory yesterday after an American judge ruled that the federal government could not sue the British cigarette company as well as its US subsidiary.
fields.body:
BAT celebrated a legal victory yesterday after an American judge ruled that the federal government could not sue the British cigarette company as well as its US subsidiary.

Shares in BAT jumped 33.75p to 437p in London as investors welcomed the decision by Judge Gladys Kessler in federal court in Washington to remove BAT as a defendant from a wide ranging case brought by the US justice department.

Brown & Williamson, BAT's American subsidiary and manufacturer of Kool and Lucky Strike brands, remains a defendant in the action which had sought to recover billions of dollars spent on medical aid for sick smokers.

In a ruling that tobacco analysts regard as positive for the industry, Judge Kessler rejected the federal government's efforts to claim damages under the American Medical Care Recovery Act and the Medicare Secondary Payer Act.

In a note to investors delivered after the verdict, Martin Feldman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, described the judgment as "moderately more positive than we had anticipated". However, the judge did allow the government to pursue claims that the industry had deceived the public on the dangers of smoking under American racketeering laws.

If the government is successful in mounting this part of its legal action it could demand so-called disgorgement of profits made by the tobacco industry since the 1950s.

webTitle: Cadbury opens talks over purchase of Orangina

fields.headline: Cadbury opens talks over purchase of Orangina
fields.trailText: Pernod Ricard yesterday confirmed that it is in preliminary talks over the sale of its Orangina soft drinks business to Cadbury Schweppes.
fields.body:
Pernod Ricard yesterday confirmed that it is in preliminary talks over the sale of its Orangina soft drinks business to Cadbury Schweppes.

Though no price has yet been set, the deal is expected to raise around FF5bn (£476m) - the amount offered by Coca-Cola last year before the acquisition was blocked by the French government.

If the Orangina sale goes ahead, it will be the latest in a series of deals within the global beverages industry. Cadbury has already agreed to buy the Snapple soft drinks business in the US, while Pernod has teamed up with Diageo to buy the wines and spirits arm of Seagram.

A spokesman for Pernod Ricard in Paris said: "We are having talks with [Cadbury Schweppes] but we have a confidentiality agreement, so we cannot give any more details."

Cadbury, the prospective buyer, was reticent about the sale, warning that the talks "may not lead to an eventual agreement".

Orangina is profitable, but Pernod Ricard is focusing on its core wines and spirits business and does not have the resources to develop the Orangina brand internationally at the same time. The business employs around 1,000 people, mainly in France.

The move comes amid a change in strategic direction for Cadbury, which last year sold off most of its non-U.S. soft drinks to Coca-Cola for $1bn (£685m) to focus on US soft drinks and expand its global confectionery business.

But difficulties in pulling off a big confectionery deal have caused investors unease over Cadbury's large cash pile and forced it back into the drinks arena, with deals in the US and Australasia struck this month.

"Cadbury is likely to find bigger deals and bigger savings in the beverage market than in confectionery," said food industry analyst Andrew Saunders at HSBC.

Paradoxically, Cadbury's plans to sell its mainland European soft drinks business to Coca-Cola were blocked by European regulators, and now France is Cadbury's third largest soft drinks profit centre after north America and Australasia. Its shares were down 1p to 400p.
