fields.headline: Can you dig it?
fields.standfirst: Never put off until spring what you can do in autumn, says Christopher Lloyd. So get digging now, then prepare to sit back and enjoy as your plantings take hold over the long winter months
fields.trailText: Never put off until spring what you can do in autumn, says Christopher Lloyd. So get digging now, then prepare to sit back and enjoy as your plantings take hold over the long winter months
fields.body:
It would be hard to exaggerate the importance of autumn planting. If you possibly can, do it now, rather than delaying until spring. The ground is warm now, so anything hardy that you plant will quickly get established, even if it does appear to be dormant. No plant is ever fully dormant. That is all relative. Yes, you probably will need to water in, and possibly quite thoroughly, but that is far more easily achieved than coping with a spring drought. Once settled in, your autumn plantings will look after themselves and will be able to cope with a spring drought, too.

The chief argument brought against planting now is the damage that a hard winter could incur. Well, it is easy enough to defer planting things that are known to be on the tender side, but if only a slight risk was involved I should take it. Remember the run of mild winters that we are enjoying, and take advantage of the situation, whether it is caused by global warming or not. We seem to hear nothing but moans and dire predictions in respect of that; the advantages to us gardeners are crassly overlooked. That is because of the human delight in shaking grizzly locks and predicting the worst. Have nothing to do with all that.

The advantages of autumn planting are easily named. Delay until spring, and you'll be pushed for time during a season when everything is on the move and so the job may well end up being put off for yet another year. Daylight saving lasts until the end of next month, so the working day is not yet unreasonably short. All spring-flowering perennials will flower well if settled in now, but they may do so poorly if you leave it until spring, particularly if their roots have to be disturbed.

The emphasis on spring is, these days, largely motivated by the garden centres, which prefer to offer their customers plants that are already obviously full of promise - flowering, if possible - and so enable them to cash in on the human urge to get busy when a cheerful spring day reminds us that winter is over. If you have sufficient vision to inter a plant that visually has no appeal at the time of handling it (surely that is not asking too much), you will be streets ahead of those who are guided entirely by impulse. Of course, impulse gets the better of all of us on occasions, and is momentarily a great thrill, but it shouldn't guide all our actions.

If it's wet when you need to plant, work off boards so that you don't congeal the soil (I'm thinking of our clay) with your footprints. If the foliage of bedding plants - polyanthus, sweet williams and wallflowers, in particular - is wet, the mess you get it, yourself and your tools into is most frustrating. Try to choose air-dry conditions.

If planting trees in turf, don't open up the holes to receive them days, or even a day, before you are ready to plant. An intervening rain will ruin your plans, whereas newly opened-up turf is always friable. For the same reason, if you are replanting perennials in a border - phloxes, for instance - leave their cutting down until you're ready to get busy on lifting and splitting. Beneath their dead or dying remains, the ground will always be workable, even on heavy soil, but not once exposed to the elements. Another reason for leaving the plant until you're ready to deal with it is that you won't have to remember about its height and habit. It will be there in front of you. The same with its neighbours. That is why I am against the wholesale cut-down operations that some gardeners are so fond of weeks or months before they are ready to do the real work of lifting, manuring and splitting.

Another thing: cutters-down habitually leave quite a length of stem on the plants they cut. True, these act as a reminder as to the plant's whereabouts, but these dead stems, when dried and hard, can deal vicious jabs and also harbour hibernating earwigs and other pests (as well as ladybirds and other beneficent insects, but it is best to keep quiet about them when pursuing an argument). If I really do need a reminder of where each clump in a group is, I leave just one shortened stalk and remove that once its purpose has been served.

When replanting a perennial with a dense mass of roots and dormant shoots, pull or chop it apart and use it only for replanting the strongest pieces, which are usually located on the outside of a clump, where there was least competition. How big should the pieces be that you replant? That varies with the perennial. I don't want to wait a year before I get a good display, so with phloxes, again, I replant pieces that have several dormant buds, rather than just one. With vigorous, suckering Michaelmas daisies, on the other hand, one shoot with roots attached will be enough, because these single shoots will, in the very first season, make a great branching aerial structure that is perfectly capable of filling a large space with masses of blossom. You learn as you go along.

I don't believe in a periodic holocaust, either, replanting an entire border every so many years. The piecemeal approach is far more satisfactory. Indeed, in a mixed border there is no alternative. Make up your mind which groups are looking tired (best seen when still growing) and replant them, leaving the rest for another year. So, I would replant some phlox groups, but never all in the same year

Yes, you probably will need to water in, and possibly quite thoroughly, but that is far more easily achieved than coping with a spring drought. Once settled in, your autumn plantings will look after themselves and will be able to cope with a spring drought, too. The chief argument brought against planting now is the damage that a hard winter could incur. Well, it is easy enough to defer planting things that are known to be on the tender side, but if only a slight risk was involved I should take it. Remember the run of mild winters that we are enjoying, and take advantage of the situation, whether it is caused by global warming or not. We seem to hear nothing but moans and dire predictions in respect of that; the advantages to us gardeners are crassly overlooked. webTitle: Dulcie Domum: Where there's a will...

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Where there's a will...
fields.standfirst: Ghastly taste fills mouth. Eyes itch furiously. Maybe I'm allergic to myself
fields.trailText: Ghastly taste fills mouth. Eyes itch furiously. Maybe I'm allergic to myself
fields.body:
Alice has arrived. Must postpone discussion with aged aunt about her desire to change her will in my favour. "We'll talk it overrr when your frrriend's gone home, dearrr," whispers aunt. But what if Alice stays so long that aunt forgets, dies, or has a better idea involving Bosnian orphans? Tortured by financial as well as erotic longing - but must not think of Fred.

Alice fills the fridge with several packs of mozzarella. Though she is no longer vegan, the buffalo is the only bovine she is not allergic to. My eyes itch. I may be allergic to something, too. Probably Alice.

Harriet and I escape to the supermarket in search of politically-correct food. No mad meat, endangered fish or vegetables produced in third-world monocultures. "What about cake?" cries Harriet, grabbing iced fancies.

"Not Mr Kipling!" I cry anxiously. "Kipling was the poet of imperialism."

Uneasily aware that the woman on the checkout just might be one of Harriet's friends from primary school. It looks like Gabrielle, only about 30 and deeply veiled in mascara. Mind you, Harriet has changed out of all recognition, too. Our tots have become tarts.

Drive home with Doritos and guacamole, hoping they sound Nicaraguan. Also macadamia nuts. Macadamia: Madam, Academe, Tarmacadam. Ambushed by pornographic image of professor having his buttocks resurfaced.

"Give me a handful of nuts, Harriet!" My eyes itch again. Perhaps it is a deficiency. Gobble handful of macadamia nuts while stationary at traffic lights. Congratulate myself on having avoided thinking about Fred for at least half-an-hour.

Luckily, Harriet did not realise that Fred and I were having a fling. She considers it impossible that anyone should fancy her mother. If, indeed, he did fancy me. Thanks to syringing, the insides of my ears are now sparkling and glamorous, but the rest of me is a shambles. No one would give me the eye now. Even conjugal affection balks at conjunctivitis.

Suddenly aware that there is a small, hard object similar to a shotgun pellet in my mouth - a filling has come out. Pull over and spit into hand.

"For God's sake, Mum! Gross!" Tongue conducts rapid search of teeth and reports huge hole at the back, on the right-hand side. Ghastly taste fills mouth, as of industrial accident in Poland. Eyes itch furiously. Perhaps I am allergic to myself.

"Ugh, Mum! Your eyes are, like, pink!" Pink is not a fashionable colour right now, so this is a double faux pas. Suddenly remember suffering something similar exactly a year ago. Perhaps it is a seasonal allergy. Perhaps I am allergic to autumn and middle age. Season of cysts and mellow ruefulness. Rejoin queue of traffic. Nearly home. Enjoy last few peaceful moments of quality time with my daughter, who is reading a clothing catalogue. "Mum! Can I have a Cradle of Filth Rape and Ruin T-shirt?"

Eyes itch increasingly. By the time we get home, I am frantic for cold compresses. Alice is in bathroom and aunt is in cloakroom, so open fridge and slap a couple of packs of mozzarella over my eyes. Begin to feel the rising fury inevitable when one is separated from one's beloved bathroom by an interloper. My tear ducts are filling up with pus and I urgently need to apply Sensodyne to my stinking new cavity.

Alice eventually emerges.

"Your shower is very eccentric," she moans. "I had to juggle with it for hours just to get a tepid widdle." Mentally remove Alice to a deep pit, where she is urinated on by aardvarks for eternity. "Oh, by the way, some bloke phoned. Frank. No - Fred? Said he was in town and he'd drop in later - well - any time now, I suppose." What, now? Apart from the pus-filled eyes and the breath like a blowtorch, my chinos are so liberally spattered with food stains, you could boil them up and make a nourishing soup. The front doorbell rings. I lock myself in the bathroom and prepare to flush myself down the lavatory.

"Mum! Fred's arrived, and he's got the holiday photos! There's one with you looking like a gorilla!"

Hmm. Must have got my good side, then.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Mandawuy Yunupingu
fields.trailText: Mandawuy Yunupingu
fields.body:
Mandawuy Yunupingu is in his fifties. He was the first Aboriginal to gain a degree, and is the lead vocalist with Yothu Yindi, a band that has toured the world with its mix of rock and traditional tribal music. He was named Australian of the Year in 1992. Yunupingu addressed millions of people in a human-rights speech broadcast on millennium eve. Yothu Yindi will perform at the closing ceremony of the Olympics on October 1.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

People living together in perfect harmony respecting differences in culture.

What is your greatest fear?

Losing my culture.

Which living person do you most admire?

My older brother, Galarrwuy, who is involved in Australian politics.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?

Forgetting lyrics on stage.

What makes you depressed?

People's lack of awareness of what we're doing to the earth.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

Not being properly dressed for an important occasion.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

Fuck you.

What is your most unappealing habit?

Alcohol.

What is your favourite smell?

The fragrance the morning after a brush fire, when the morning dew sparks new life.

What is your favourite building?

The paper-bark shelter.

What is your favourite journey?

The search for the truth.

What is your favourite book?

Cry Freedom, by Donald Woods.

How did you vote in the last election?

'Yes' to Australia becoming a republic.

Do you believe in capital punishment?

Yes, for extremist crimes.

For what cause would you die?

For human dignity.

Which living person do you most despise and why?

Pauline Hanson. She's disrupted development of the Australian way of thinking.

How do you relax?

Sitting around having a beer with family and friends.

How often do you have sex?

As much as possible.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

Advancing indigenous existence without fear.

How would you like to be remembered?

As a man who built a foundation for generations to come.

webTitle: The knowledge: shell out on ... mussels

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Shell out on ... mussels
fields.trailText: Shell out on ... mussels
fields.body:
The subject

Mytilis edulis and relatives. Principal refuge of bivalviraptors, since a dozen oysters cost more than a second-hand Audi. Currently hitting their stride in the Scrumptious Stakes as the cold weather sets in.

The basics

Mussels are farmed all over coastal Euro-land, as well as in the UK. The so-called beards are remnants of the byssus, the strong filament with which they attach themselves to the poles, rocks or rafts on which they spend their three years of life.

The details

What the Knowledge loves most about mussels is that they're delicious, but not so costly that you can't mess around with them.

What we hate: cleaning them is a pain. But a mussel man's gotta do what a mussel man's gotta do. Within reason, anyway.

Non-negotiable cleaning: discarding specimens with broken shells, or that refuse to close when rapped, squeezed hard or insulted.

Fully negotiable: scraping off barnacles - not altogether necessary, unless you are entertaining important guests.

Ideal lag between buying, cleaning and cooking: 0 seconds.

Maximum lag: 24 hours in the fridge.

Knowledgeable certainty: mussels go with everything , not just the allium/wine/parsley triad of marinière fame. Think Chinese, Spanish, Indian, Thai, Italian, etc.

Mussel man's workout buddies: cured pork products, a recklessly spicy dipping sauce, ginger, cream. If you don't think life's too short to stuff a mussel, check out Richard Olney's Simple French Food.

Overrated mussel number one: New Zealand green-lipped - precooked, frozen, texture resembling well-cooked radial tyres.

Overrated mussel number two: big dudes - tiny French moules de bouchot are the best anywhere.

Where to buy

Any place that sells fish, but use your eyes: large proportion of open shells = superannuated shipment.

The easy way out

Bribe someone to clean 'em. Tinned mussels? Texture of soggy cardboard, flavour of fishmeal. The Knowledge would rather go hungry.

fields.headline: Less is more
fields.standfirst: Buy saffron in small quantities - you won't be able to afford to do anything else, anyway
fields.trailText: Buy saffron in small quantities - you won't be able to afford to do anything else, anyway
fields.body:
Saffron and cardamom are two of the great exotics, sought after by princes, potentates, panjandrums and, of course, chefs. Made from the hand-picked stigmas of the purple Crocus sativus, saffron has, not surprisingly, always been of fabulous reputation, equalled only by its price. Cardamom is no less distinguished, however, its various forms being celebrated in the Mahabharata, lusted after by the Romans and celebrated in Chinese poetry.

Although neither originated there, both spices come together in the cooking of southern India, where they are used sparingly. Both have powerful flavouring qualities, which, if used in excess, bring out unpleasant, bullying and, in saffron's case, markedly bitter tones. Separately, they have marched through the culinary cultures around the world.

The British have had a particular affinity for saffron, perhaps because the crocus actually grew in our climate. The curiously named Saffron Hill in the City of London is so called because it was once part of the gardens of Ely Palace, where saffron was grown, presumably for abstemious bishops. And the arms of Saffron Walden, Essex, bear three saffron flowers, a mark of when it was the centre of saffron production, its heyday being Tudor times. It found its way into a host of dishes, as well as buns and cakes, which is a splendid Cornish tradition that is still very much alive today. In retrospect, however, it seems rather odd that it was never used to bring colour and pizzazz to a stew of the fish that are native to our waters, in much the same way that countries around the Mediterranean have done.

As with all spices, you have to treat saffron with respect. I have already noted its bullying tendencies if used with a heavy hand (although they are no worse than the herbs rosemary and sage), which may go some way to explaining why saffron has not always had the best press in these matters. The great herbalist, Nicholas Culpeper, noted that it was a "useful aromatic, of a strong pungent bitterish taste", while the French gastronome and writer, Alexandre Dumas, described it as near fatal. However, when it comes to adding the drama of colour to a dish, few spices can match saffron, and its distinctive flavour adds a curious and pleasing note.

Because of the laborious nature of its production (and the consequent great cost), there is probably more fake saffron about than any other spice. You can find good quality saffron from Kashmir and Turkey, although the best comes from La Mancha in Spain. Remember that heat and, in particular, light are the enemies of all spices, so buy it only in small quantities (you probably won't be able to afford to do anything else, anyway) when you need it.

Cardamom similarly loses its vitality when kept for too long. Pliny was spot on when he said that the green pods are the best, but if you're really picky check that the seeds inside are still sticky - if not, those heady aromas to which the Arab world (and, oddly, Sweden and Finland) is so addicted as a flavouring for coffee will be mere shadows. Likewise, ground cardamom. If you are a serious connoisseur, you will insist on your cardamom being the pale green Alleppey cardamom of Kerala, although it is grown all over southern India, Sri Lanka and Indochina, as well as Tanzania, Guatemala, El Salvador and New Guinea.

Cardamom, like saffron, has a complicated history. There was some confusion in ancient days between Amomum cardamomum - or "false" or "bastard" cardamom, which the Greeks and Romans set great store by - and what was designated Elettaria cardamomum , which we know and love today. Quite how the former or the latter found their way into common usage has been obscured by wars, invasions and other such matters, although by the first century AD, Pliny was able to establish that there were four grades of cardamom, and Andrew Dalby in Dangerous Tastes (British Museum Press, £16.99) gives us a recipe from the "illustrious Vinidarius", which puts him in mind of one of Jeeves's pick-me-ups that produced the feeling that "somebody had touched off a bomb inside the old bean and was strolling down my throat with a lighted torch".

Perhaps it isn't surprising, then, that cardamom is a relative of another potent spice, ginger, and was most probably introduced to India from the east, where it was originally appreciated more for its medicinal qualities - as a decongestant, in particular - than for its culinary ones. Bearing in mind these characteristics, while saffron and cardamom pair happily in rice, whether for stuffing or as an accompaniment, it is as well to remember that with these spices less is definitely more.

All recipes serve six.

Saffron broth This is a wonderful way of using the broth left over after cooking the chicken below. The delicate liquid is freshened up with some chopped, lightly cooked vegetables and then simmered. A few spoonfuls of an aromatic vinaigrette are added just before serving.

1.5 litres chicken liquor (from cooking the bird, above)
2 medium courgettes
2 small onions
6 spring onions
1 leek
3 plump, ripe tomatoes
2 tbsp fresh peas (if available)
1 generous pinch saffron
1 clove garlic
1 small handful chopped parsley
1 tbsp chopped coriander leaves
2 tbsp very good olive oil
1 tsp white-wine vinegar
Salt and pepper

Wash the vegetables. Top and tail the courgettes, and cut them into small, vaguely square pieces. Peel the onions and leek, and finely chop them. Remove the eye from the tomatoes and finely chop the flesh.

Put the strained liquor into a generous pot and bring to the boil, skimming off any foam that rises to the surface. Add the onions and courgettes, reduce the heat to a gentle simmer, then, after 10 minutes, add the peas, leek and saffron.

For the vinaigrette, trim and thinly slice the spring onions. Chop the herbs and garlic, and place them in a bowl with the spring onions, olive oil and vinegar. After the soup has been simmering for half an hour, stir in the vinaigrette and serve at once.

Poularde à la d'albufera I remember a dish of boned chicken stuffed with saffron rice that I cooked years back, and it has since become an old friend. The original version of the recipe was named after the Maréchal Suchet, who was made Duc d'Albufera by a grateful Napoleon, after the general's victories in Spain. It is an elaborate dish that I have simplified somewhat here, though, by removing the truffles and foie gras, I suspect that I have merely made it cheaper. The addition of cardamom is a happy one. Once the dish is prepared, it is elegance itself to serve.

1 2.5kg top-quality free-range chicken

For the stuffing

2 chicken livers and 1 chicken heart (they should be in a little bag inside the cavity of the bird, along with its giblets)
40g unsalted butter
2 medium onions, peeled and finely chopped
60g white rice
35ml white wine
35ml Noilly Pratt (or other white vermouth)
430ml chicken stock
1 generous pinch saffron
6 cardamom pods, cracked
1 bayleaf
Salt and pepper
1 egg

Cut the livers and heart into smallish pieces, then fry in just a little of the butter in a heavy-based pot for 45 seconds or so. Transfer to a plate and melt the rest of the butter in the pot. Fry the onions over a gentle heat until softened. Add the rice and stir for two minutes or so, until it becomes translucent. Pour in the white wine and vermouth, then add the chicken stock, saffron, bayleaf, cardamom and a little pepper. Leave the rice to cook, undisturbed, for 15 minutes, until just done. Add the fried liver and heart, and then gently scrape the whole lot into a large bowl. Carefully stir in the egg, then cover and leave to cool.

Meanwhile, carefully make an incision along the centre of the breastbone and cut out the two breasts. With a pair of scissors, cut away the exposed breastplate. Season the inside of the chicken with salt and pepper. Put the cooked rice inside the chicken, pushing it gently into the cavity and up against the backbone. Replace the breasts of the chicken on top of the rice, thereby emulating the bird's original form, and with a trussing needle and thread, sew the breasts back together. Finally, tie the bird in several layers of muslin until completely secure. Place the bird in a very heavy pot along with:

2 peeled carrots
2 peeled onions
1 stick celery
1 clove
4 cardamom pods, cracked
1 bayleaf
50ml white wine
The breastbones from the bird

Fill the pot with ample water to cover the bird and bring to a simmer. Once bubbling, skim off any foam that rises to the surface, then put a lid on the pot and leave to cook quietly for an hour and a quarter. Turn off the heat, and leave the fowl to sit in the stock for at least half an hour undisturbed.

1 can frozen concentrated orange juice
3 large eggs
tsp salt
175g caster sugar
6 cardamom pods
300ml whipping cream

Thaw the orange juice in advance. Whisk the eggs and the salt with an electric beater. fields.bodyText: Saffron and cardamom are two of the great exotics, sought after by princes, potentates, panjandrums and, of course, chefs. Made from the hand-picked stigmas of the purple Crocus sativus, saffron has, not surprisingly, always been of fabulous reputation, equalled only by its price. Cardamom is no less distinguished, however, its various forms being celebrated in the Mahabharata, lusted after by the Romans and celebrated in Chinese poetry. Although neither originated there, both spices come together in the cooking of southern India, where they are used sparingly. Both have powerful flavouring qualities, which, if used in excess, bring out unpleasant, bullying and, in saffron's case, markedly bitter tones. Separately, they have marched through the culinary cultures around the world. The British have had a particular affinity for saffron, perhaps because the crocus actually grew in our climate. The curiously named Saffron Hill in the City of London is so called because it was once part of the gardens of Ely Palace, where saffron was grown, presumably for abstemious bishops. And the arms of Saffron Walden, Essex, bear three saffron flowers, a mark of when it was the centre of saffron production, its heyday being Tudor times. It found its way into a host of dishes, as well as buns and cakes, which is a splendid Cornish tradition that is still very much alive today. In retrospect, however, it seems rather odd that it was never used to bring colour and pizzazz to a stew of the fish that are native to our waters, in much the same way that countries around the Mediterranean have done. As with all spices, you have to treat saffron with respect. I have already noted its bullying tendencies if used with a heavy hand (although they are no worse than the herbs rosemary and sage), which may go some way to explaining why saffron has not always had the best press in these matters. The great herbalist, Nicholas Culpeper, noted that it was a "useful aromatic, of a strong pungent bitterish taste", while the French gastronome and writer, Alexandre Dumas, described it as near fatal. However, when it comes to adding the drama of colour to a dish, few spices can match saffron, and its distinctive flavour adds a curious and pleasing note. Because of the laborious nature of its production (and the consequent great cost), there is probably more fake saffron about than any other spice. You can find good quality saffron from Kashmir and Turkey, although the best comes from La Mancha in Spain. Remember that heat and, in particular, light are the enemies of all spices, so buy it only in small quantities (you probably won't be able to afford to do anything else, anyway) when you need it. Cardamom similarly loses its vitality when kept for too long. Pliny was spot on when he said that the green pods are the best, but if you're really picky check that the seeds inside are still sticky - if not, those heady aromas to which the Arab world (and, oddly, Sweden and Finland) is so addicted as a flavouring for coffee will be mere shadows. Likewise, ground cardamom. If you are a serious connoisseur, you will insist on your cardamom being the pale green Alleppey cardamom of Kerala, although it is grown all over southern India, Sri Lanka and Indochina, as well as Tanzania, Guatemala, El Salvador and New Guinea. Cardamom, like saffron, has a complicated history. There was some confusion in ancient days between Amomum cardamomum - or "false" or "bastard" cardamom, which the Greeks and Romans set great store by - and what was designated Elettaria cardamomum , which we know and love today. Quite how the former or the latter found their way into common usage has been obscured by wars, invasions and other such matters, although by the first century AD, Pliny was able to establish that there were four grades of cardamom, and Andrew Dalby in Dangerous Tastes (British Museum Press, £16.99) gives us a recipe from the "illustrious Vinidarius", which puts him in mind of one of Jeeves's pick-me-ups that produced the feeling that "somebody had touched off a bomb inside the old bean and was strolling down my throat with a lighted torch". Perhaps it isn't surprising, then, that cardamom is a relative of another potent spice, ginger, and was most probably introduced to India from the east, where it was originally appreciated more for its medicinal qualities - as a decongestant, in particular - than for its culinary ones. Bearing in mind these characteristics, while saffron and cardamom pair happily in rice, whether for stuffing or as an accompaniment, it is as well to remember that with these spices less is definitely more. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Cheap reds sampled by Malcolm Gluck
fields.body:
Surely £2.79 for a cabernet sauvignon has to be some kind of joke, doesn't it? Of course it is. We can smile as we satisfyingly glug, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer can guffaw as he sneaks off with more profit from the wine than any participant in its manufacture, distribution or sale. But this is a Bulgarian wine, so that's all right, then. How long such prices can be maintained now that the Bulgars are inching into the real world (ie, one with no subsidies) is anyone's guess, but as far as Tesco, which sells the wine under the non-vintage Reka Valley label, is concerned, so far so good. And this wine is good, being a solid cabernet with firm, rich tannins of impressive demeanour. It rates 14.5 points (out of 20), and goes splendidly with bangers and mash.

Tesco would have you pay 69p more for its own-label Fitou, from which you get a mite more in the fruit department. The wine has charm and character, and the cherry-rich jamminess of the fruit is well-controlled, putting up with no unruliness from the earthy tannins. It rates 14.5 points and costs £3.48.

With the Chilean Santa Catalina Merlot 1999 (Tesco, 16 points, £4.49), we enter a somewhat more sumptuous arena. There are fumacious riches here, of the cheroot variety, and the fruit, harnessing this aromatic intensity to great effect, is deep, rich, savoury and broad-shouldered. It is hardly a quaffing wine - it's far too concentrated for that - but with roast meat or spicy vegetable dishes it would be superb.

Errazuriz Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £5.79) is also from Chile, and there is a very distinguished feel to the wine as it courses over the taste buds, proving, if any further proof were really necessary, that Chile makes abundantly toothsome chardonnays with exceptional textures at remarkable prices (notwithstanding the Chancellor's customary rapacity). Domaine Cazal Viel Viognier 1999 (16 points, £5.99) is also a treat, offering subtle apricot fruit, lemon edging and a hint of nuttiness. This is a lovely, elegant wine of some class that compares favourably with more expensive viogniers, a chic Rhne white grape, from Condrieu.

Normans Unwooded Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Australia, has utterly gorgeous, buttery, slightly baked richness and depth, but none of that lust-to-be-liked which often makes Aussie chardonnays so over-the-top and unbalanced. Last at Tesco (and Thresher, incidentally), there is, from Argentina, 'Q' Tempranillo 1998 (16.5 points, £7.99). This is what more riojas should be like: energetic, rich, tobacco-tinged, deep, jammy but dry, and full of flavoursome layers of surprises.

Now, if one wonders how Tesco achieves some of its prices, what about our friends at the Co-Op? The CWS's Romanian Prairie Merlot 1999 (14.5 points) is down to £2.59 until October 15 and, though no great claims can be made for its complexity, it soothes the tongue and warms the heart. Adiseno Tempranillo 1999 (15 points, £3.99), from Argentina, does all this, too, but also clogs the throat, too, for it's as thick as a wine sauce, and just as meaty and rich. 'Laid Back Ruby' California Ruby Cabernet 1999 (15 points, £3.99) bristles with food-friendly fruit, offering an unusually bravura performance from the much-despised ruby cabernet grapes.

Mission Peak Argentine Red (15.5 points, £2.99, also at Booths) has marvellous texture, rich fruit and throbs with pleasure-giving generosity and depth. Mission Peak Argentine White (15.5 points, £2.99) is also a delicious bargain, parading rich yet not obscenely plump fruit, and is marvellous with fish curries. Goiya Kgeisje Chardonnay Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (15 points, £3.99), from South Africa, also likes fish, but not of the spicy sort, since this wine's deft blend of soft fruit and crisp acids - where ogen melon and pineapple/ lemon freshness harmonise so purposefully - is delicately poised, and so simple grilled mackerel with herb butter is perfect.

Last, another £2.79 bargain, news of which reached me only as this column was going to press (slapped wrist, Somerfield). This is that retailer's scrumptious own-label Chilean Sauvignon Blanc 1999, which is beautifully compacted with 16-point gooseberry fruit and frisky on the finish. It stays in its lowly state until October 3 only.

webTitle: The new logo for British farmers doesn't mean quality

fields.headline: Mr Nice Kind British Farmer
fields.standfirst: The "Little Red Tractor"  logo is a sign of 'quality', claim farmers. It isn't, says Joanna Blythman
fields.trailText: The "Little Red Tractor"  logo is a sign of 'quality', claim farmers. It isn't, says Joanna Blythman
fields.body:
When are British farmers going to stop taking consumers for fools? The latest manifestation of their patronising attitude is the "Little Red Tractor", a logo straight out of nurseryland. The National Farmers' Union wants us to believe that products bearing this logo have been "produced to exacting food hygiene, environmental and animal welfare standards". In other words, it guarantees that your food comes from Mr Nice Kind British Farmer, not Monsieur or Señor Nasty Johnny Foreigner Farmer. It's all rather reminiscent of those Enid Blyton stories in which the heroes (all nice white boys) expose the villains (sallow, shifty, with funny foreign accents). Forget concerns about GM food, pesticides, antibiotics, food poisoning and BSE. The plucky British tractor sweeps all these aside: "It will be a promise to shoppers that, when they see it, they are buying food they can trust," says NFU president, Ben Gill. But what, exactly, underpins the promise ?

For decades, British farmers have sought to reassure consumers about the provenance of their food by setting up quality-assurance schemes for various food sectors - lamb, chicken and so on - producing a proliferation of flags and logos on produce that suggest to consumers that what they are buying is superior in some way to something else. However, what that something else is, precisely, is left to the imagination.

When you examine such industry-generated quality-assurance standards, however, it becomes blindingly obvious that they fall way short of the all-embracing guarantee that consumers seek, and in general represent only a very slight improvement on standard practise that is just above the legal minimum. To put it more bluntly, these assurance schemes are marketing gimmicks whose role is to pat consumers on the head and say, "There, there, don't you worry", without dealing with real concerns. The little red tractor simply rationalises most (though not all) of these proliferating quality- assurance schemes into one brand.

So if, for example, you buy little red tractor chicken, that bird can still be kept in an overcrowded broiler house. "The red tractor chicken standards actually allow birds to be stocked at a higher density than is recommended by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, not to mention the EU's scientific committee on animal health and welfare," points out Peter Stevenson of Compassion In World Farming. Similarly, a red tractor apple can be grown with just as many pesticides as any other apple. As for red tractor pork, the NFU has been at pains to suggest that there is a huge welfare advantage for consumers in buying British pork, because sows cannot be kept in tethers in the UK, a very selective and misleading reading of the facts: the red tractor logo can still be slapped on pork from pigs that have been intensively factory-farmed in every other way.

The long and short of it is that any sweeping assertion that British is always best is simply not sustainable. The truth is that if you were to sit down and systematically compare food-production standards in the UK with standards elsewhere, you would come up with pluses and minuses on both sides, and no overall winner. But the NFU is stuck in an ideological time warp that prevents it from addressing consumer concerns in an honest and practical way. It seems to think that nobody but farmers understands farming, and so most of the time doesn't want non-farmers sticking their noses in where they don't belong. Even if they do, the NFU seems to think it can palm them off with a partial, sanitised version of reality and a knee-jerk appeal to patriotism.

So, when not clobbering Johnny Foreigner over the head with its new little red tractor, the NFU has lately taken to reminding consumers of just how ignorant they are. Recently, it commissioned a survey that showed that "an alarming 70% of the British public have no idea what food the farmers in their local area produce". But is this any wonder, given that our farmers have actively discouraged non-farmers from taking an interest in the less than savoury practices that go on down on the farm? Even supposing that wire fences and signs depicting raging bulls don't do the trick, the blacked-out windows of the malodorous industrial units that are our modern farm buildings don't exactly scream out "open doors".

There are, of course, many sound reasons for buying local food - the NFU is not alone in believing that it is ludicrous that the UK imports food that it could easily grow - but if we are being asked to support British farmers' produce on the basis that it is qualitatively better than foreign competitors - a judgment based on a variety of different indices - then the facts must be seen to bear that out.

After all, even a child can understand that it's not good enough just to shout out that your tractor is the best. It has to be the best

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Black Cat
fields.trailText: Black Cat
fields.body:
Mild ale has come back from the dead. The great beer style of Victorian England that was eclipsed by bitter and pale ale in the mid-20th century is enjoying a revival, boosted in part by Moorhouse's Black Cat, from Burnley, Lancashire, winner of the cherished Champion Beer of Britain award from Camra this summer. It is 3.4% alcohol, has a superb aroma, and features coffee and chocolate flavours (from the use of dark, well-roasted chocolate malt).

There are rich fruit flavours, too, and a good underpinning of bitter hops from the traditional Fuggles variety. The finish is lingering, with delightful notes of roasted malt. Black Cat mirrors the style of north-western milds, which were made a tad fuller and hoppier than normal during the 19th century, to compete with the popular Guinness Stout that was being exported from Dublin to Liverpool. Black Cat is available on draught and, since its success at Camra's awards, is now available wholesale throughout the country. For stockists, call Moorhouse's on 01282 422864/416004.

webTitle: Art and the Paul Hamlyn Awards

fields.headline: Five-card trick
fields.standfirst: Artists have never made much money unless they are taken up by a gallery or rich patron - all the more true of the new wave of neo-conceptual artists who, post-Tracey and Damien, have a more political edge. Which is why the Hamlyn Awards provide a welcome break from the day job and the dole
fields.trailText: Artists have never made much money unless they are taken up by a gallery or rich patron - all the more true of the new wave of neo-conceptual artists who, post-Tracey and Damien, have a more political edge. Which is why the Hamlyn Awards provide a welcome break from the day job and the dole
fields.body:
The board game, Doley, was invented by Paul Noble, one of the five artists who have won this year's Paul Hamlyn Awards. It is a game "for three or more players over the age of 16", who choose to be represented by one of five characters on the board, Oblivious (& Other-worldly), Burnt Out, Formless & Misshapen, Ineffectual, and Aimless. "You are now a player in Doley," explain the rules. "This is what happens to you. Once every two weeks you sign on and then, a couple of days later, your Giro comes. Sometimes your Giro comes in the second post, which means hanging around, watching the letterbox, waiting for the postman ..."

The postman has brought something much nicer for Noble and the other winners of the Paul Hamlyn Awards, Philippe Bradshaw, Jim Lambie, Hilary Lloyd and Hew Locke. Each of the five has been told that they will receive £30,000, to be paid in three annual instalments of £10,000 - with no strings attached.

The Paul Hamlyn Awards are different from any other British art prize. This is no Turner, where one of the nominated artists walks away with the prize and the rest spend the next few years getting over the whole thing. The Paul Hamlyn Awards have previously been given to artists in other fields, including composers and poets, but since 1998 have been dedicated to visual arts (publisher Paul Hamlyn's daughter, Jane Hamlyn, who runs London's Frith Street Gallery, is the guiding force).

The aim is to provide artists with a secure income with which to nurture creativity, as well as to reward achievement. This is especially welcome for artists who do not currently make a living wage from their work and so have to supplement it with other forms of employment (or, like Noble, spend years on the dole). The judges consider need as well as merit.

For many of us, it is hard to get too tearful about the lot of young artists. British art is rarely out of the papers, the wallet of Charles Saatchi is celebratedly capacious, and if artists have to supplement their income with day jobs, so what?

If you went to a museum in New York in the 60s and 70s, the person taking your ticket was probably a famous artist in the making (the monochrome painter Robert Ryman and Jeff Koons both worked as attendants at the Museum of Modern Art), and if you went to the legendary toy shop FAO Schwarz in the early 70s you might have been served by Robert Mapplethorpe. Going back further, in the 50s Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg were able to keep working only because they formed a business designing window displays for Fifth Avenue stores.

Artists have been half-bourgeois, half-social outsiders ever since they won independence from traditional systems of aristocratic patronage. Artists earn almost nothing until and unless they become stars, names, figures of a certain perceived significance in contemporary art history.

"To be successful as an artist," wrote Andy Warhol with candour, "you have to have your work shown in a good gallery for the same reason that, say, Dior never sold his originals from a counter in Woolworth's ... If a guy has, say, a few thousand dollars to spend on a painting, he doesn't wander along the street until he sees something lying around that 'amuses' him. He wants to buy something that's going to go up and up in value."

There is a huge division between the handful of artists whose work is valued in this way and the rest for whom the occasional sale is less about a serious contribution to their income than a sign that they are, after all, an artist rather than a teacher or a decorator. In Britain today, there is a vast culture of making art, but most people who call themselves artists will never make an income from their work - until they were taken up by Jay Jopling's White Cube, for example, Jake and Dinos Chapman, notoriously, were penniless.

Artists of the post-YBA generation are particularly skint. The style of new British art has changed, and these neo-conceptual artists, often with a political edge to their work, don't expect ever to sell that much. The Paul Hamlyn Awards are particularly suited to this new climate in the British art scene. But they are also prizes, a recognition of talent, and the five artists who have been rewarded this year include some of the most promising figures around.

Philippe Bradshaw makes kinky decorations for the modern home. His art has a decadent, rococo feel, and his affinities for the 18th century were made explicit when he reproduced Jean-Honoré Fragonard's cheeky painting, The Swing (1767), in the Wallace Collection, as an image glimpsed in the shiny links of a screen of chains. This piece of chainmail erotica - combining the soft frilly art of Fragonard with a hard, modern material, fragmenting a historical work of art in a field of glimmer and glamour - is typical of the work Bradshaw is doing.

Until recently, Bradshaw was, with Andrea Mason, part of a collaborative duo, Andrea + Philippe; they carried out site-specific interventions with a subversively decorative quality, on one occasion glazing abandoned wartime bunkers around the country and offering these desirable residences for sale at a phoney estate agency that they had set up in a gallery off the King's Road. "This brick-rendered hexagonal pillbox has a flat concrete roof with jutting corners," went one parodic estate agent's blurb under a colour photo of a ruined military structure in south Wales. "It is easily accessible via a brick porch entrance. Inside ... two pairs of pink panties have been casually tossed into the corner."

Since 1998, however, Bradshaw has been working on his own, and his art has become increasingly sensuous and aesthetically ambitious, offering visions of sexy, voluptuous interiors. He plans to make a chain forest, in which he will project images from the story of Hansel and Gretel, and a chain waterfall with a papier-mché coracle. He says he will use the money to "establish a secure studio" and "invest in a computer and digital editing set-up".

Jim Lambie is a psychedelic nostalgist. In ZOBOP (2000), a work that can be installed in any room, he covers the entire floor in groovy, concentric bands of multicoloured vinyl. The bands of colour vibrate and dance like a poster from Haight Ashbury; orange, magenta, lime green. ZOBOP suggests that changing the world begins at home, with a bit of crazy interior decor. We colour walls, we colour doors - why not floors? Do we leave floors plain (in today's anti- carpeting age) because they make the world feel more solid beneath our feet? If you lived with Lambie's Technicolor floor, would it change anything?

Lambie's art looks back to a time when delirium was the tool of revolution and altered states of mind were actively pursued. At the same time, ZOBOP is a formally seductive work of art, evoking abstract painting. Twentieth-century art wanted to disrupt perceptions, destroy preconceptions and open up new Utopian ways of seeing things; Lambie wittily links these high ideals to hippy colours and psychedelic pop.

Lambie, who studied at Glasgow School of Art, is one of the growing number of Glasgow-based artists who are making an international impact. Like other artists who work in the city, he combines dreaminess and wit, and his art is hugely engaging. The thing he hopes this award will give him is, he says, "time" - to plan and develop new work in an unrushed way. He also plans to get a proper studio.

Hilary Lloyd is a Warholian observer of young people, their manners, preoccupations, dress. She makes videos of studied nonchalance, which she shows simply on TV monitors mounted on steel pedestals. There is a joke about sculpture, especially the forgotten art of portrait sculpture, in the way she shows her work. Her videos are portraits; they feature young people not doing much, wasting their time in stupid games, or doing less than that - Monika (2000) tries to build a house of cards; Dawn (1999) just sits in a chair in her lime-green suit. We are invited to study them, to see what we can see about them.

Warhol is a specific rather than general source: Lloyd's pieces resemble his Screen Tests, in which an unblinking camera would watch people mercilessly as they tried to be funny or broke down and cried. Lloyd is more collaborative with her subjects, and the method of display makes her work more intimate. The monitors are at average human height, so it's as if we are seeing someone in the room with us. At the same time, it is like coming face to face with an 18th-century statue or portrait bust.

Hilary Lloyd is radically different from the video artists who emerged in the early 90s: whereas, say, Douglas Gordon and Steve McQueen are intensely cinematic, she is resolutely small-scale, televisual and deliberately slight.

Hew Locke recently created an installation at the Victoria and Albert Museum called Hemmed In II. Bulging, growing, bursting between porphyry pillars in the museum's vast entrance hall, it resembled a building, perhaps a bathhouse, a market or a religious building - it was hard to tell. In its organic clutter, it seemed to be a parody of the rambling V&A itself. Locke's architectural jumble - made of nothing but cut-up cardboard stuck together with glue - was the unconscious of the museum spilling out, and the work of an artist who messes about at the margins of high culture.

Born in Edinburgh, Locke went to school in Guyana and has said that when he returned to Britain he felt for the first time that he was seen as "other". His response has been to make art that engages with European high art, doing grotesque charcoal and pastel drawings based on Velázquez and Hogarth and, with Hemmed In II, confronting the V&A with its jokey other, at once a celebration and travesty. Next year, he will develop further work in museums with a residency at the Horniman Museum in Forest Hill, south London. He is also developing his long-term plan to build a structure large enough for people to walk into, the Cardboard Palace.

Paul Noble is a kitchen visionary, a brilliantly original satirist and producer of vile dreams whose work has almost nothing in common with what we think of as contemporary British art. Noble is a politically-minded artist - he is co-curator of the exhibition Protest And Survive at the Whitechapel Gallery - who communicates a detailed vision of the world through drawings, paintings and other activities.

However, it is the drawing project he has been working on since 1995 that is Noble's most impressive achievement to date. He is the planner and administrator of Nobson Newtown, a modern British community that he has mapped out from the Nobslums to the Lidonob to the Nobjobclub. Noble's drawings resemble the work of MC Escher, logically extrapolating basic forms. These forms are the letters of a computer font he has designed - called Nobson. The town has its own history, archaeology and geology; in Introduction To Nobson Newtown, Noble recounts how it was built out of a unique stone found in the Nobhill Downs called Nobrock, which the earliest inhabitants of the area mistook for "the fossilised remains of God's brains".

In fact, Nobrock consists of language. Every building in the town has what it is written in its fabric; the Nobslums, built in a pit into which raw sewage cascades, are little houses made of letters that together say "nobslum". In his latest book, Noble portrays Nobson in ruins - a cross between Milton Keynes and Pompeii. The fact that it is built out of language makes you feel it is full of secret meanings and that real life, too, is written according to a secret language in which history, location and politics determine who we are.

Nobson is an image of narcissistic and tyrannical creativity - within the town Noble gives himself The Architect's House (Paul's Palace). Noble says he wants to use his award to complete Nobson Newtown - every building, with its elaborate construction, takes him six months to draw - and the money will be especially welcome as he has been surviving by paying low rent on his studio and living in a squat, but "this is all due to change".

The British art scene today is full of young artists who say the last thing they want is to be the next Damien Hirst or Tracey Emin. Forget glamour and provocation; say hello to books of theory and the pursuit of idiosyncratic ends.

It's an inevitable reaction, repeating the history of the 60s, when the glamour of Pop was rejected by the late 60s generation who turned to conceptual art that rejected the market. Yet it's a tricky business pinpointing precisely what's going on in contemporary British art. One moment, it looks as if art has returned to colour and decoration and all the things conceptual artists are supposed to hate; the next, young artists are all political, dry-as-dust thinkers - the tendency reflected in Intelligence: New British Art 2000 at Tate Britain.

The truth is, the best artists around now are developing obscure, even eccentric lines of thought that are not connected to any movement or fashion; Paul Noble is one of these major talents, and if there were a first prize in the Paul Hamlyn Awards it should go to him. The unstarry, unpressured Paul Hamlyn Awards are perfectly suited to this mood, encouraging artists not to worry about anything - except making art

Philippe Bradshaw born 1965

From Lincolnshire. Studied at Goldsmith's College. Couch Potato has real potatoes growing on it. Self Portrait As Ping Pong Umpire In The Folies Bergères and Two Sisters are video projections on to anodised aluminium curtains. On show at Tragic Data, Lux Cinema, Hoxton Square, London N1.

Hilary Lloyd born 1964

Born and raised in Yorkshire. Studied at Newcastle upon Tyne Polytechnic. Her videos portray apparently banal everyday human activities (or inactivities). Maddy And Kate was shown as part of an installation last year. Constructors is one of a series of video stills. Lloyd's work is included in the current touring British Art Show.

Paul Noble born 1963

Raised in Northumberland, studied at Humberside College. His large-scale pencil drawings are part of an ongoing project, Nobson Newtown, a fictitious town in which the buildings are designed according to an alphabet created by Noble. Public Toilet is one of the series; Welcome To Nobpark is an installation view of the drawings. The Doley Game dates back to 1996.

Jim Lambie born 1964

Studied in his home town at Glasgow School of Art, and still lives and works in the city. His involvement in the local music scene has had an influence on his work. His works include: Psychedelic Soul Stick, Plaza, and 3 Minutes. His work appears in the Dream Machine show at Camden Arts Centre until October 29. Lambie will soon take up a residency at the World Trade Centre, New York.

Hew Locke born 1959

Born in Edinburgh, educated in Guyana and now lives in London. Trained at Falmouth School of Art and the Royal College. His work Hemmed In II was installed in the V&A, then moved to the Norwich Art Gallery and is now part of the Norton Collection, California. Red Menace part of Locke's Menace To Society series, is made up of a doll, toy gun, fake hair and artificial flowers.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya gets worries by the petrol crisis
fields.body:
Two weeks have gone by, but the turmoil of those uncertain days remains seared on my mind. After the recent drama over petrol and the titanic clash between market forces and the environment, I decided to find a third way. I explored fuels other than the wretched Opec juice. Among the sites I found under 'electric car', I was most impressed by www.car-stuff.com, with its broad range of links, dealers and much relevant information.

However, image matters, and none of the electric cars looked nearly as cool as the VW Beetle. Thanks to www.volkswagen.com.br, I discovered that the Brazilian version of the Beetle is powered by sugar-cane alcohol. Just imagine: no blackmail from the sheikhs, no fuel tax from Gordon... The only problem is that sugarcane alcohol is not that easy to find here (Bacardi is even more expensive than Shell's best), so I'd have to import a tanker-load of the stuff from Rio. It might be more realistic to do like the Queen and convert my car to liquified petroleum gas. Pleasantly scented, highly eco-friendly and lightly taxed (I mean the fuel, but HM is, too). The only drawback of LPG is that you can find it only in a few petrol stations for the time being. If you are interested, check www.autogas.co.uk.

Fighting with a ghastly woman at our local late-night shop over the last loaf of bread (and it wasn't Duchy of Cornwall organic!) made me realise the importance of essentials. Never again will I be caught unprepared. I ordered a bread-maker from www.divertimenti.co.uk, and www.breadworld.com has recipes for every type of bread I can think of. Next time farmers and friends revolt, I'll be able to come out to my minimalist Zen-inspired terrace and shout: 'Laissez-les manger du gateau!' ('Let them eat cake' - www.learnfrenchlanguage.com).

 Email Tanya at: tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk; or visit her website at: www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

Thanks to www.volkswagen.com.br, I discovered that the Brazilian version of the Beetle is powered by sugar-cane alcohol. Just imagine: no blackmail from the sheikhs, no fuel tax from Gordon... The only problem is that sugarcane alcohol is not that easy to find here (Bacardi is even more expensive than Shell's best), so I'd have to import a tanker-load of the stuff from Rio. It might be more realistic to do like the Queen and convert my car to liquified petroleum gas. Pleasantly scented, highly eco-friendly and lightly taxed (I mean the fuel, but HM is, too). The only drawback of LPG is that you can find it only in a few petrol stations for the time being. If you are interested, check www.autogas.co.uk. Fighting with a ghastly woman at our local late-night shop over the last loaf of bread (and it wasn't Duchy of Cornwall organic!) made me realise the importance of essentials. Never again will I be caught unprepared. I ordered a bread-maker from www.divertimenti.co.uk, and www.breadworld.com has recipes for every type of bread I can think of. Next time farmers and friends revolt, I'll be able to come out to my minimalist Zen-inspired terrace and shout: 'Laissez-les manger du gateau!' ('Let them eat cake' - www.learnfrenchlanguage.com).  Email Tanya at: tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk; or visit her website at: www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Isn't it ironic that your interview with Naomi Klein (Hand-To-Brand Combat, September 23) is surrounded by huge, gleaming advertisements for multinational corporations?
fields.body:
Isn't it ironic that your interview with Naomi Klein (Hand-To-Brand Combat, September 23) is surrounded by huge, gleaming advertisements for multinational corporations?

As Klein herself points out, 'There's no escape ...'

E Mavroudi
Edgbaston, Birmingham

I, and most other ordinary-ish 40-ish people like me, don't give a stuff about logos and labels, and could only stand helplessly by as teenagers killed each other for designer rubbish. Now Naomi Klein wants to lecture me on how misguided I've been ... hmmm.

But, of course, apart from her continuing but now negative obsession with corporate identities, she has got a point. The corporations targeted our kids, and now they are reaping the whirlwind - it's more than a mere mum can do not to say, 'Serves you bloody well right.'

It is, however, difficult not to notice that the Klein piece appeared on the same day as the simply delicious Fashion & Beauty supplement, which advocates silly designer handbags and shoes at £300-£400. I hope you have an understanding with the black-clad forces of the global emporium, or you might well find Klein at your door next.

Anne Sweeney
Lancaster

In an article on the power of symbolism in global capitalism, it was neat of you to put a photograph of Bill Clinton on the same page as one of a model for Gap. The Republicans really could learn a thing or two from Weekend about subliminal messages.

Simon Burton-Jones
Bromley, Kent

So, Naomi Klein, a rich Canadian, has thrown away her Nike trainers and galvanised the forces of anarchism. Maybe next week you could tell us that the Beatles invented rock'n'roll, that David Beckham invented football, and that Keith Flett was but a figment of my imagination.

Colin Billett
Bewdley, Worcestershire

Naomi Klein's No Logo brilliantly demonstrates how capitalism stinks. The big question, which Klein ducks, is how to change the system. Perhaps the protesters in Prague have the germ of a solution.

Keith Flett
London N17

Julie Burchill (September 16) including David Baddiel in the same sentence as 'Nazi Germany and fascist Japan'? What has he ever done, other than make thousands of people laugh and, no doubt, pay a couple of million pounds in taxes, with obvious benefits for Britain?

The fact that Baddiel's grandparents escaped Nazi Germany makes her comment even more deeply insulting and ignorant.

Rachel Foot
Wraxhall, Bristol

Was Ken Russell (The Questionnaire, September 23) not asked, 'How often do you have sex'? If he was, was the answer unprintable?

Richard Proctor
London SE13

I have almost finished page 15 of the Slow Down issue (September 9). Is this a record?

Alan White
London E6

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
